results.content:
I took this course to supplement my JS knowledge and it did not disappoint. One thing I really appreciated was how the Brad would go over how to code something in ES5 syntax, and then again in ES6—I found that very helpful, personally.

My only suggestion would be to update the WeatherJS API project lectures so that it's not referring to Weather Underground because trying to understand Open Weather while listening to a lecture about Weather Underground was jarring and made the material difficult to pick up. In fact, I skipped that project entirely (thankfully I've worked with Open Weather before).

Other than that, I would highly recommend this course to anyone wanting to bolster their JS knowledge. :)

results.content:
I would give this course 4.5 stars if it were not for the fact that the two major API exercises do not work.  There is nothing more frustrating than an exercise that does not work!!

I start by assuming that the mistake is mine and I waste a lot of time trying to figure it out.  I did discover that GitHub has left REST behind in favor of some other technology.  I really wanted to see that exercise work.

The weather does not work either although the instructor was kind enough to leave students a note that says the API now costs money and that someday he will rework the class to use another API.  No idea when or if I will even be alive by then.

results.content:
The course is not bad, and I think the structure is well done if a bit fast paced. I have two concerns so far:

1) There's no discussion about online materials to help the beginner navigate the API. Rather than plunge into the code, why not show the student where to look up functions?

2) The projects aren't really projects. They are just videos of Brad showing you how to do the work. It's not presented as an opportunity for the student to try out what they've learned, and come back and check themselves. I think more work to actually lay out the project is needed.

---------------

Update (half-way through course): - Good overview of the material, and Brad explains the concepts very well. Really easy to follow. He doesn't skip around and the videos build on each other nicely. There's also a good amount of repetition that helps reinforce what Brad's teaching.

I still wish there was a teach to fish rather than show approach. For instance, maybe spend a video on each section dealing with a new portion of JS APIs actually reviewing the Mozilla web documentation for orientation rather than just spring new methods on the student.

Also, it's totally up to the student to get the most out of the class by trying their hand at the code before watching Brad do the work. It's way too easy to be completely passive and pretend like you're learning.
results.content_html:

Excellent course. This is just what I wanted, pure vanilla JavaScript. I know that there are a lot of libraries and frameworks out there that enhance and improve the experience with the language, but there is nothing better than first knowing the core language concepts.

results.content: This is a very comprehensive course on pure JavaScript with no frameworks.  Starting with some basic work in the console, it works up to some fairly developed apps; this course covers a great deal of ground in a hands-on approach.  The API projects section needs a little update due to the change in the Github API, I was able to adapt the weather API project to another weather API; I think that these are very important projects to work on.  The last section on Microposts is very interesting as it appears to bring the course on verge of modern frameworks.  However, the section is a bit rushed and needs more intro as well as a few more steps on the setups.  If you want to learn JavaScript from the ground up, this is definitely the course to take.  Brad's knowledge of Web Dev clearly shows as he walks you through the projects.
results.content_html: This is a very comprehensive course on pure JavaScript with no frameworks. Starting with some basic work in the console, it works up to some fairly developed apps; this course covers a great deal of ground in a hands-on approach. The API projects section needs a little update due to the change in the Github API, I was able to adapt the weather API project to another weather API; I think that these are very important projects to work on. The last section on Microposts is very interesting as it appears to bring the course on verge of modern frameworks. However, the section is a bit rushed and needs more intro as well as a few more steps on the setups. If you want to learn JavaScript from the ground up, this is definitely the course to take. Brad's knowledge of Web Dev clearly shows as he walks you through the projects.

results.content:
Overall a good course with great effort put into mini-projects, which I salute. 

Pros: 
- plentiful of small, hands-on projects, not only for practicing skills, but also for building upon them and already creating an own portfolio of apps
- Code in the projects is wonderfully structured, helps with the learning
- The instructor has the ability to present content in an easy way
- learning VanillaJS prior to learning libraries and frameworks
- optimal length 
- good selection of topics 
- beginner-friendly, yet not trivial
Cons:
- Explanations of more complex topics not clear/ in-depth enough for me, had to do a lot of research aside from watching the videos. I'm not expecting everything to be explained to me by just one instructor, but I do believe that there are courses that are better in this respect, where not every single more complex topic needs to be googled

In summary, for a deeper dive I'd go for another course, but for starting with js, HTML and CSS, and getting practical very quickly, this is still a really good course.

In summary, for a deeper dive I'd go for another course, but for starting with js, HTML and CSS, and getting practical very quickly, this is still a really good course.

results.content:
From what I've seen so far Brad is doing an excellent work teaching the ins and outs of Javascript, which is exactly what I was looking for. Might be a tad hard on complete beginners, but I suspect that later on in the course, everything will be put into perspective.

Update: I just finished the course and I must say it is a great one for people who really want to deeply understand Javascript. However I still believe that beginners will really have a hard time with it (I know I've struggled and it's not my first language). It's a lot to take in and it certainly requires a revisit in order for everything to properly sink in but it's a great reference and I'm really glad I took the course.

results.content:
This has been quite a challenging course for me. I really appreciate Brad's depth of knowledge and teaching skills. That said, where I stumbled along the way is in part due to the jumping around in the code, occasional changes in direction, and mistakes. I spent hours troubleshooting errors as a result, and while some amount of that is useful experience, at some point it significantly detracts from the learning experience. 
I found the Tracalorie and MicroPosts projects daunting. Having all the code in a single app.js file for Tracalorie I feel led to my having coding errors along the way. At times the shuffling back and forth through app.js made it difficult to follow and keep up. While I realize that the number of lines of code in app.js are modest by commercial standards, I feel that a different partitioning could be more helpful for learning.
The MicroPosts project was also frustrating, and finallly in the end, I stopped coding at about 117 and just adopted a "learn by observing" approach. The implementation of webpack in this project was not fully explained, and in the end when my code was failing and I used the code supplied with the course, I often saw the same errors. Webpack made it more difficult to track the sources of errors, and I wasn't aware that 'npm run build' was an important step in resolving the problems.
In the end, I'm glad to have taken this course and want to acknowledge it was one of the more challenging I've completed on Udemy.

results.content: The instructor is very informative, knowledgeable as well, and keeps your attention with ideal pace, not to quick or slow. Just about right. The only setback from my viewpoint as a student was 8th section when initially used API ceased to be a free one. That caused some issues I couldn't fix alone and there was no reply from the support. At that point I decided to enroll other JS courses on Udemy. After that I returned to complete this course and found out that although being very knowledgeable about the subject Brad has lost his way towards the end of the course. Mixing to much ES5 with ES2015 just to avoid utilization of WebPack is a wrong teaching path in my opinion. Regardless of that I consider Brad one of the best teachers on Udemy and benefited greatly from his CSS course. I'm sure he'll improve this one as well in the future.

But, all in all, money well spent. Thanks Brad!

results.content: The material is so valuable. So many tools and tricks learned. I will not recommend this course for absolute beginner, you should have some expertise with Javascript or another programming language. If you have those prerequisites then be ready to learn how front-end user interface interactivity works under the hood. Frameworks are great, also we can really get the most of them when we understand problem they tend to solve. Going through this course you will enjoy using those frameworks and learn to avoid then! That is, for DOM manipulations, user alert, basic Javascript CRUD, data storage and lot more ...

results.content:
This is a solid and comprehensive course on the practical side of JS. 

I say practical because it never goes into full detail on the way the language works behind the scenes, which is really useful to know—things like how the this keyword binding works, the event loop, hoisting, and the workings of prototypal inheritance etc. More extensive implementations of Object Oriented Programming can also highly valuable to get into.

For learning about those things and (in my humble opinion, as I'm still learning them myself) in order to call yourself a true JS developer, I recommend books like Eloquent Javascript and the You Don't Know JS series to boot.

All in all, Brad is a great instructor, straight to the point, pragmatic and hard-working. He has a ton of courses and all are truly well made. 

Thank you Brad.

All in all, Brad is a great instructor, straight to the point, pragmatic and hard-working. He has a ton of courses and all are truly well made.

Thank you Brad.

results.content: This course was great overall. I didn't go for five stars though because there are some areas that I thought were badly explained and I had to go elsewhere for a lot of information (particularly around what prototypes actually are and how promises actually work). Also, it seems that so much of JS is passing parameters into functions, and defining those parameters using arguments wherever that function is called. This distinction between parameters and arguments never actually gets explained on this course: you have to figure it out for yourself. The final two projects were EXTREMELY well explained, and it would have been great if the whole course was explained to this level. Overall though, I'm really happy with what I got out of it.
results.content_html: This course was great overall. results.content: I enjoyed Brad’s HTML & css class, but this JavaScript class lacks many of the features that made the first course excellent for beginners. There’s a fairly wide knowledge gap between the introductory sections and the projects, and not enough explanation of how you approach determining which JavaScript features you need in order to accomplish a specific task. The projects quickly became an exercise in code copying, so I’m stopping midway and starting over with a different course. This one felt more geared towards more experienced programmers.

results.content: This course has been fantastic. After working through an interactive JavaScript course on another self-paced platform, my goal was to gain additional context and study how some of these concepts actually transferred into applications. Brad's course structure, explanations, and experience has been quite exactly what I needed. While I felt like I was mostly understanding these concepts in the abstract prior to the work I've been doing in this course, I did not feel like I understood how to transfer them into independent projects. More importantly, I didn't feel confident that I was learning to think like a JavaScript programmer. This course and the skills that Brad teaches have enabled me to start practicing independently, which feels like a pretty huge step from where I was several months ago. I highly recommend it.

results.content: I am already literate in JavaScript, but am taking this course, and a few others, to prepare for teaching an in person course. I thought it would be great to see how others approach teaching code. Having taught classes to beginners, in the past, there is a glaring omission in this course. As a person is learning about variables, functions, arrays, etc, they need the opportunity to use them, on their own. I realize you can't do a lot with only the basics, but part of learning to code is learning how to think. Giving small assignments where the students must come up with a solution is critical to their success, if they plan to use this skill in a job situation. In this course, all the basics are taught clearly, but you just sit and watch him code, with no opportunity to use what you have learned. I find this to be a deal breaking omission for those taking the class, with no prior experience. I realize this probably changes, as you get further into the course, but without hands on practice, much of what is watched in the videos, will likely be forgotten if it hasn't been used and practiced.

results.content:
Actually, I would like to split the rating: 4 stars for the first half of the course, 2 for the second half. Brad does a great job explaining the fundamentals of the Javascript language, DOM manipulation, etc. Even though I'm not new to programming, I learned a lot and enjoyed trying out the projects on my own before watching him code them. I highly recommend you do the same. You'll have a much better experience this way. At least, until roughly the second half of the course when it starts to derail. 

I don't doubt that Brad knows what he's talking about, he just isn't a teacher and this becomes apparent as topics get more advanced. Imagine someone tried to explain to you how to build a house by saying: "Okay, here's a door. You put the roof up there, oh, there is also a wall, no several walls. And a kitchen sink." You would quickly get confused. A proper teacher would start with the foundation and then build on top of that, one floor after the other until you get to the roof. Unfortunately, this doesn't happen here.

You will gain a basic understanding of JS by taking this course. If this is your goal, by all means, buy it. If you expect more, you might be better off somewhere else.

results.content:
HEADS UP! BEST REVIEW COMING HERE!

Well, Hello! This is a detailed review on this course. I have sat through all the lectures, practised or noted most of the lectures and this is what I have got for you guys who wants to learn JS.

First of all, Brad is self taught expert in the Full Stack Domain and it is very clear.
There are both pros and cons.

Pros:
1) The lectures are very tight, I think its not lengthy.
2) Clearly mentions all the key points and "Nothing goes unexplained"( I will come back to this)
3) Definitely  worth the money and time.
4) Made for a Beginner, who wants to learn JS quickly and cover most of it.

Cons:
1) There are topics where you got to sit through where Brad writes or says stuff and you have nothing to do expect to listen to him. These  are the key points. Once said, He never repeats it in most of the cases which he does so, will help a lot!
2) The Q&A is not at all responsive! No one answers the damn questions not even Brad.( Applicable to all his courses)
3) If the projects are not practised, Baby you have learnt nothing except Ctrl+C and Ctrl+V .

This is my guide to successfully enjoy this course.

Most of the time, I make notes on the course, revise it daily. Whenever a project starts, he does give an overview on how the project is going to be. This is where you gotta give the try. Pause the Video, try to do it on your own. If successful, see how he does it and why. If not, no worries, try it for next step. This is where you actually learn. Those who says he just keeps on coding and does nothing are really a bunch of wussies and they got to actually code it than see him code.

Final Conclusion : Course worth time and money, Revise it , Practise it and you will be fine.

results.content:
Overall, I appreciated the comprehensiveness, including the breadth of examples/projects and guidance regarding development setup and tools (e.g., VSCode, Webpack, JSON-Server).

However, a few of the examples were overly contrived, and in some cases did not even really seem to demonstrate the intended concept. The most egregious case was the State Pattern project. The PageState object neither stored state nor changed state and was completely superfluous. UI state changes were entirely driven by event handlers and calls to individual functions that directly updated the DOM (even those functions were unnecessarily made into object generators, even though they stored no state and had no methods). I suppose this project had the superficial form of a state pattern but did not actually implement one.

Elsewhere, there were also examples of classes that held no state and could just as well have been a collection of independent functions.
results.content_html:

results.content:
Good fit for me.  I like the brisk pace, resources included, Brad's vocalization is soothing which is good for long experiences.  As I went all the way through, I really was able to appreciate the whole concept of starting with modern JS, sans frameworks.  I believe this is exactly what I needed.  I am an experienced developer, having mostly done .NET in recent years, but never ground up web development (other than assisting and following direction from a lead dev).  It is quite different.  In many ways pretty easy to follow but without the thoughtful curation Brad provides, it would be much more difficult.  I recently learned Python from not having had much of a roadmap, and it took longer to feel comfortable.  Plus, Python as I have learned it thus far has been much more similar to my previous non-web experience.  By comparison, JS is "weird" in how it requires all the knowledge of DOM, HTML, browser, CSS, multiple types of libraries and add-on tools, and so on, all working together.  The workflows are different, and without an organized course like this, it would be wandering through the forest I think.

Anyway, on to building my first real hands-on web application.  After I get a ways on this, I plan to refactor it into Vue as a second step, to learn how it all plays together.

results.content:
This isn't my first course from Brad Traversy and won't be the last.

I have learned HTML, CSS course from him, also.

Actually I would give him a 5 star if:
- I think the design patterns is some kind of extra. So judging him with this issue may not be so fair. However, in spite of writing codes, giving the students introductory information would be better. I am sure, Brad is able to do this.

- He should have explained AJAX and Async methods more clear in Section 7. I needed to do a lot of web search. Actually the video on his youtube channel provides most missing information about this issue. And maybe it is better to get used to do web search.
- He creates javascript files primarily on ES5, and then shows how to make transform into ES6 version. I think the opposite would be better, since we are expected to know ES6, or in another words latest styles more in job applications.

results.content:
I could write a never ending novel about why Brad Traversy is such a great instructor but I will try to sum it up in short. 

Brad is extremely knowledgeable, he knows his programming and does not waste your time with half baked explanations or bad principles.

Brad is very structured, he created a very structured course with a carefully designed syllabus and it shows ! 

The syllabus includes a lot of hands on work. You do not just learn JavaScript, you learn how to build with JavaScript which is by far the most important thing for aspiring developers.

In Summary : 

Excellent Instructor + Excellent Syllabus = Excellent course !

results.content: I really enjoyed taking this course from Brad. He really covers all of the bases of JS and does so in a concise and engaging manner. This was perfect for me as a Comp Sci student who was already familiar with a few other programming languages and I'm excited to begin Brad's other courses in React and node.js. My best piece of constructive criticism is that sometimes I feel that Brad can gloss over some topics where a bit deeper of explanation for them might be warranted to get a better understanding of what's really going on underneath the hood in JS.  For those times I would look over documentation or some outside sources to try and fill in the gaps for myself. But you if want an absolutely solid course to bring yourself up to speed with all the various parts of JavaScript you can't go wrong with Brad's course. I don't regret a second of the 21 hours I spent going over every subject presented here.

results.content:
I really wish I had read David Dugay's review before I purchased this course because it describes exactly how I'm feeling at this point. I'm about halfway through the course and feeling very disappointed. Excerpts from David's review that eloquently explain my issues with the course are below:

I don't like how he reviews code or copies and pastes sections of code by just saying "I'm going to change THIS to newVarialbe" or "I'm going to copy THIS and put it HERE". Personally, this makes it hard to follow what he's doing and where he is doing it at. I often need to scrub back and forth multiple times in the video to find exactly what line/section of code he's referring to.

He's a decent teacher, but I am also not a big fan of him reviewing new concepts and writing code for 10 minutes demonstrating functions, loops, and code and saying "you don't have to understand any of this yet, but we'll need it in the upcoming project". Personally, I find it easier to learn when an instructor introduces 1 or 2 concepts, then slowly adds more detail while building the project or writes 1 version of the project, then adds complexity/features after the "basic version" is completed.

I don't learn well when somebody throws a dozen new things at me in 10 minutes, then expects me to remember to use them over the next 30-60 minutes of "class" just because he says "remember how we initialized this variable and needed to use this parser to convert this data file to an array?"

My review of Brad Traversy's Modern Javascript course is mostly a matter of "a difference in my learning style vs his teaching style". I'm about halfway through the course. I understand it, I intend to finish it, but I wish I had chosen an instructor that had a teaching style that worked better for me.

results.content:
I came to this course with no prior knowledge of JavaScript technology, but with good background in Java and in C, so at first I was scared by the perceived sloppiness of the language. It took me some effort to learn and accept that type declaration is not required, how the semicolon is optional etc. But once we've got to EC2015 with modules, everything started making a bit more sense again.
The quirky function declarations still scare me a bit though. 
But the course is very good in laying the strong foundation. It is really important to actually type-in all programs, not only to read through the text. It will help to develop the muscle memory and reduce the number of errors.

results.content: Learning Javascript is a difficult process for real beginners.  If you are unfamiliar with computer languages, repetition will be important for you to learn these concepts.  This course has very little repetition, so you will have to take that upon yourself. I had to take another Javascript course alongside this one.  Both had their flaws.  This one simply isn't made for the learning process a true beginner must go through to learn from scratch.

results.content:
There's a lot of words, terms, etc used so far that mean absolutely nothing to beginners and that come off as incredibly intimidating and demotivating. eg DOM Manipulation, UI Events, jQuery, Object Oriented Programming, Async JS, Ajax, Fetch, Promises, Async, Await, Error Handling, Regular Expressions, LocalStorage, Github, Programming Scope, Arrow Functions, repository, environment, tag, Map, Set, Iterators, if statements all *don't mean anything* to somebody who truly has 0 programming experience. 

This course could be improved by either not using those terms just yet, or explaining them in plain, simple english as they appear. Eg "An environment is just a place on your computer where you can use code".

I love Emmet and Live Server.

Thanks.

results.content:
Brad is easily one of the best instructors I have learned from. I have a university computer science background and the projects Brad provides are better than the uni projects. I enjoyed working on these projects and was a great way for me to learn. As I saw solutions to the projects I want to work on coming from the code in the projects we did. I will be able to directly take what I have learned and feel comfortable in moving forward in my own projects now.

Lastly, I felt a great deal of passion from Brad about his work.  I have heard him say that Web Developer is the best job out there during his videos several times, and it feels like he really means it everytime. This means a lot to me, I have sat in classes physically to listen to somebody simply reading powerpoint slides with no enthusiasm in their voice at all. It can really kill the learning environment when this happens. You won't get that here.

I will certainly be taking more of Brad's courses.

results.content:
In general I feel this course was excellent value for money.  As an experienced developer new to JS I feel like I now have a good grasp of the fundamentals.

I've a number of complaint, which I'll enumerate at the end, but I don't think they have too bad an impact on the overall quality and depth of the material.  

Well worth my money.

My problems with the course:

ES6 content is too often taught as an extra with the focus on learning the ES5 version.  While I agree with showing both, once the ES6 has been introduced it should be stuck to for the rest of the course (e.g. some example still use ES5 classes well after the simpler ES6 classes are introduced).

There are a lot of pauses, corrections, backtrackings and umms/errs in the material that makes it feel a bit like a university lecture rather than pre-recorded course where I'd expect slightly higher production materials.  Each video is obviously recorded in one shot with no editing.  Generally it's fine but if your trying to follow along in vscode at the same time as watching, pausing to experiment here and there, you can end up going down rabbit holes only for him to correct himself 10 seconds after you resume the video.

Finally, there are a couple of errors in the course (e.g. the error handling in the async await version of the  easyhttp library project isn't correct) and one whole example that no longer works due to a public API change (not his fault but it should have been fixed by now its been broken for a while).
results.content_html:

Well worth my money.

My problems with the course:

ES6 content is too often taught as an extra with the focus on learning the ES5 version. While I agree with showing both, once the ES6 has been introduced it should be stuck to for the rest of the course (e.g. some example still use ES5 classes well after the simpler ES6 classes are introduced).

There are a lot of pauses, corrections, backtrackings and umms/errs in the material that makes it feel a bit like a university lecture rather than pre-recorded course where I'd expect slightly higher production materials. Each video is obviously recorded in one shot with no editing. Generally it's fine but if your trying to follow along in vscode at the same time as watching, pausing to experiment here and there, you can end up going down rabbit holes only for him to correct himself 10 seconds after you resume the video.

Finally, there are a couple of errors in the course (e.g. the error handling in the async await version of the easyhttp library project isn't correct) and one whole example that no longer works due to a public API change (not his fault but it should have been fixed by now its been broken for a while).

results.content: I'm at 24 days in and I passed the half way mark. I do this everyday 1.5-2 hours a day before work. I took my time to refactor the TODO list and did a detour to learn more about higher order functions in JS. But I also skipped two projects because I felt like I understood what was going on enough. He doesn't necessarily write perfect code (lots of redundancy in the todo list app for example, so I fixed it!) but I am learning javascript ES6, ES5 and now ES7 (async/await).  My tip is to save all code, do your own projects too, don't just follow along, learn, do try new things. I am understanding the material, just trying to get it to stick long term, luckily I see lots of projects ahead to practice. After 24 days I'm still feeling pretty good. My background is in Java, dart, B.S. in computer science.

results.content: even though this course is for all levels, i highly suggest read the book : a smarter way to learn javascript by Myers before attemping/taking this course because you are likely be confused by the way Brad teaches, when he talked about object literals, he doesn't explain what an object is, talking about methods he doesn't explain what a function is and what properties are. if you read the book first and then take this course i believe is a good way to learn js(you get to see how other people code). so read the book first then take this course is what i recommend doing. Thank you

results.content: Rushing through many 'beginner' concepts, but leaving out many of the fundamentals. Brad has great videos on youtube but IMO this lesson is lacking, as its advertised to teach from a complete beginner level.

results.content:
Summary: Great beginner/intermediate course. Good tutor with an approach and style that doesn't irk or frustrate. Course structure builds incrementally so it doesn't feel disjointed. A solid 4.5 stars if not more. 

What's good? - Brad is a good tutor. He's known from his YouTube channel and that direct quality transfers here. It's considerably more complete and longer than the typical YouTube videos course obviously but merits the investment in both price paid and time spent on your behalf. 

What could be better? - One or two examples reference an API that has since closed down its free access so you're forced into an alternative (which is actually quite a good test really)  I would have give it 5 stars if the exercises were all maintained with APIs the learner can use, I think the weather one might throw a few people off as many beginners may lack the confidence to tackle an alternative on their own. 

Would I recommend? - Yes.
results.content_html:

What could be better? - One or two examples reference an API that has since closed down its free access so you're forced into an alternative (which is actually quite a good test really) I would have give it 5 stars if the exercises were all maintained with APIs the learner can use, I think the weather one might throw a few people off as many beginners may lack the confidence to tackle an alternative on their own.

Would I recommend? - Yes.

results.content:
This course should not be titled "... for beginners" but "write a code along the instructor". 

The practice examples are very poorly explained, there is a choice between typing in code with an instructor or having to do tonnes of research alone. The latter one means that, as a beginner you will be better off researching (w3, youtube, freecode camp) and practising on your own. If you are advanced, you may not need it at all. 

I also found in the Q&A that the instructor is rather "impolite" with his students. Shame. Requested a refund.

results.content:
The course was quite informative and helped me cut through a lot of the clutter I was encountering while studying the subject. It's given me a good reference structure for how to teach this to my students as well as an understanding of the best ordering of the subjects to achieve the goals of the course I'm teaching.

There are a couple of parts of this course that require additional effort, though if you've paid attention and taken good notes, you'll be able to get them sorted out. Check the comments for a different API for the weather app as well as for the microposts project to get the correct webpack configuration.

Overall, I would recommend this course to learn the subject from scratch.

results.content: I've dabbled in JavaScript for 15 years, mostly saving my love for Python. I want to create some more modern Web sites, so that means I need to learn JS. I've programmed for 40+ years, so I'm no newbie. But I appreciate his introductory material. There's no way to really understand the more advanced stuff without having a solid foundation. And that's what I've gotten so far (through section 10). ... And now I'm halfway. It's been absolutely awesome. His example projects are great to work through and are realistic enough that they form a solid basis for creating real applications. I've been able to get them all to work. He's also taught enough so that I've been able to modify them and make them my own.

results.content:
Update***  

I am over halfway through the course and I still stand by my criticism of too much copy and pasting. For me, when he does it, I just pause it, retype it and talk my way through the code as I retype it and the purpose of everything I'm doing. I've learned quite a bit, and the course was certainly worth what I paid for it, but I hate the copy and pasting in a tutorial for learning. I will update again at the end of the course.

I wanted to like this course so bad. The code works fine, and he does a good job getting through it in a timely fashion. The problem is that he seems to be in a hurry to get the videos done and to get the code to work, rather than explain WHY the code works and what the functions he's using actually does an how to use them more than once. A perfect example is when he uses the splice() function on an array. He passes in the index as a second argument in order to use it in the foreach loop, but when he uses the splice() function, he says to pass in the index, and then a 1 to delete the item. A bit ambiguous if you ask me. I had to stop, go to the docs and look up the function in order to see that the second parameter of the function declares how many items from the array you want to delete. Did it ruin my life? No, but an 11 minute lecture too about a half hour because I was coming back from the day before and had to go back through the code and figure out what I had done the night before (because he would just copy/paste it and move on).

Additionally, back to being in a hurry, he copy and pastes a lot of code and does not repeat the reason for writing it. For guys like myself, who split the series up over the course of a day or two, it would be very helpful to just rewrite the code, and explain what it is and why he is using it, to prevent me having to stop the video and go look elsewhere for an explanation for why he is doing it. I understand that coding in real life is very much like that. Having to reference docs a quite a bit and copy/paste to save time, but for a video designed to teach people, I don't need to watch someone code something that works and hope that I get the reason for the code on the first pass through. Perhaps I am being to tough and critical, as I said, the material in the lectures is correct and the code does work fine. For guys like me (dumb af), I need repetition of not just the code via copy and paste, but of the functions we are using and why they are necessary.  If you're the same way, I suggest you just use the W3 schools tutorial

I was looking for a refresher JavaScript course and didn't realize what "Modern JavaScript" implied. JavaScript has changed a lot  since 2012.

I was able to follow everything until the Full Stack development in the last tutorial. Then I was left behind because I needed to understand the environment and tools that professionals take for granted, not just the code. 

Brad is an excellent instructor and takes the time to explain and comment his code.

I would take any course he offers.

results.content: Brad obviously took his time to make a good, long and thorough course. This means you'll be exposed to everything you need to know about pure modern Javascript development. However, sometimes it feels like you're just copy-pasting whatever Brad is doing - which is not ideal for deliberate practice and learning, because he doesn't always do into depth with everything. All in all, great value for the money.

At the end you will have enough knowlage for learning frameworks and deeply understanding concepts how they work in plain JavaScript.

results.content:
For me it was a very clear JS presentation, putting things in order.

Maybe this it the way the presentations are made, but I prefer the examples to be faster, not with typing all the code, but sometimes to copy paste it from places, or to simply take a full already existing example and explain it. A lot of time would have been saved.
I learned to go to the latest sample, the full one and analyze it to speed the things up.

Bottom line: a very clear and useful course.

results.content: This course gives you a really great, broad introduction to the basics of JavaScript, it really helped to tie together a lot of basic concepts, and introduced some more detailed ideas that I'm looking forward to learning more about in the future. I studied this as I wanted to cover the basics before moving onto React courses, and I'm really glad I did. The breadth of content is fantastic, highly recommended.

Thanks Brad.

results.content:
This is a good comprehensive course to learn and gain some experience with the fundamentals of JavaScript. I started the course knowing what JavaScript is used for, but not how to use it. I feel like I came away with a good understanding of how to use it to create some basic applications.

I also think the course does a good job of shedding some light on how web developers think and approach their projects. I started learning Angular at the same time that I went through this course. I think Brad's examples, particularly the last 2 or 3 sections, really helped solidify some of the concepts I saw in Angular and had wondered about.

Another great thing about the course, and most of Brad's courses, is that he exposes you to a lot of tools you might not otherwise know about if you're not a web developer and don't spend time around web developers.

results.content:
Good course overall. This was my absolute first exposure to web development and I may have misinterpreted "beginning". Having some programming experience though, I was able to follow the overall gist.

The course does not provide true "try what you just learned" opportunities. I tried mirroring Brad during the first few modules but with all the times I had to stop and start the video to comprehend, code, debug, etc., I was at 20 hours before even being halfway through the course and ultimately decided just to watch. Other than lengthening the course to include less-scripted exercises, I'm not sure everything gets comprehended. 


FYI, I ran into major issues with setup in Section 13.
1. At the tail-end of the Node.js npm install, the terminal notified of several deprecations and security vulnerabilities. The recommended corrective actions prevented 'npm run build' from working. I had to rerun 'npm install' but take no corrective actions for the build to work.
2. For 'npm run build' to work, the Microposts folder has to be directly in the Desktop folder. I had nested differently so nothing worked. Suggest updating the README.md or add note file to the zip to make these requirements clear.

Good course overall. This was my absolute first exposure to web development and I may have misinterpreted "beginning". Having some programming experience though, I was able to follow the overall gist.

FYI, I ran into major issues with setup in Section 13.
1. At the tail-end of the Node.js npm install, the terminal notified of several deprecations and security vulnerabilities. The recommended corrective actions prevented 'npm run build' from working. I had to rerun 'npm install' but take no corrective actions for the build to work.
2. For 'npm run build' to work, the Microposts folder has to be directly in the Desktop folder. I had nested differently so nothing worked. Suggest updating the README.md or add note file to the zip to make these requirements clear.

results.content: Brad is a great teacher but unfortunately this course is outdated.  One of the sections involves creating courses using APIs.  There are two APIs that Brad uses, and both have been changed since the course was released.  You will not be able to replicate these API projects without outside research into how one of the APIs works.  You will also need to completely replace the other API that is used as it is not publicly available anymore.

results.content: I love Brad's YouTube videos, especially his front-end stuff. He always comes up with visually pleasing projects, however I'm not too sure I can follow along his teaching style when it comes to actual programming. The course doesn't have any challenges or any examples to use your knowledge, I have learned bits of JavaScript from various different places which has helped me understand what some of the sections are on about. I think majority of people learn best by doing things repetitively until it starts making sense. In these videos, there is very minimal explanation whilst trying to cover everything at the same time. Imagine learning the alphabet in one session! If you are a beginner, I would strongly advice to stick to YouTube as there are plenty of resources to learn all the basics and more.

results.content:
I've been coding for a few years  in C++ and Python, but recently had to get into full-stack development. I was able to get my application up and running (using html, css, jquery javascript and python) by browsing through content on w3schools, MDN, stackoverflow , etc., but I'd never taken the time to look into javascript properly. This made it tricky when working with newer libraries, particularly those relying heavily on ES6 technologies.

I was looking for a course that would help fill in the gaps in my JS knowledge, without taking up too much time. Brad's course worked out perfectly - I was able to learn everything I wanted to by watching all the videos at a sped-up rate, and coding only the occasional exercise. Personally, I was able to complete it in 3 (very intense) working days. This doesn't mean the course isn't also appropriate for beginners - Brad of course explains everything as he goes along. But if, like me, you're an experienced developers who just wants to fill in some gaps in your understanding, I can vouch for the fact that you'll find the content really helpful.

Thanks, Brad for the effort :).

results.content:
I enjoyed the course and Brad does an excellent job at explaining throughout the course and goes the extra mile to provide complete files on every lesson. I look forward to buy more courses in the future x)

It probably sounds like it is no big deal because us students should do that on our own anyway, but for people who are absolute beginners I'm sure it would benefit them greatly.

results.content:
I liked very much the course! I have done all the lectures and so on. It is about 20 hours of course. However, it took me 43 days to complete it.   It is incredible how much we could learn from Brad. It is really amazing to see how he can teach many different topics in a really nice and easy way.
What I really liked:
1) It is a course that we really learn a lot of JavaScript! It is incredible! He does not waste any minute talking thinks that does not matter. It is 20 hours of REALLY IMPORTANT INFORMATION!! For beginners, can be a bit hard to get so many information!! It is good that you know a little of JavaScript or at least a good knowledge of html and css! If you are beginner I really advice to go step by step. Stop the lectures and do some parallel projects. 
2) The projects are very well done. We used some framework as bootstrap, skeleton and so on. I really advice you also to do parallel projects to fix the knowledge learned in this course!

What I did not liked?
1) I think one negative point is that Brad does not reply any message. I understand that he does not have time. So, if you have problems, you have to figure out it for yourself or wait some help from someone here. For me, it was not a problem at all. But it is a point that you have to concern.

Conclusion: it really worth the money and the time invested! It is the best course that I have done so far!! Thank you very much Brad Traversy for this amazing work!

results.content:
Sometimes, I was so confused because of the outdated code, you have to go through the Q&A to seek the solution. Honestly, they should update some of the content by uploading a new video instead of just putting the solutions in Q&A section.

So I come back after I finish a couple of practices and other tutorials on youtube, I found that the way Brad used to teach in this course is kinda confusing, especially the complicated parts like rest api and design pattern. NOT recommend this course for those are new to JS, it would be better if you come after you have the basic knowledge.

results.content: Fantastic course. I was almost totally new to JavaScript, and Brad started from the very beginning (including key things in any language like for and forEach loops and went right through to advanced things like API's, ES6 features and sizeable applications using vanilla JavaScript. It's incredible to see what JavaScript can do and I now see why it's used so much. It also taught me bootstrap at a very basic level as some of the exercises use it to build the UI - which is a side note as it's not the topic of the course. The pace is slow and the explanation is very clear. Fantastic course. Highly recommended!

results.content:
It's like watching a minecraft tutorial when someone is going to build a giant castle made out of thousands upon thousands of blocks. You watch the guy on the tutorial place out one block, and then you put out the same block on the right space, and this process goes on and on until WOALA! 

Here stands an en epic castle right in front of you, and hopefully, when you turn a small lever, all the torches should light up. it works. Everything feels great. But then it dawns upon you, you haven't learned anything. And you are just left standing there, having no idea how built it and are sure you will never be able to build it again.

results.content:
Brad is great - I have learnt so much from this, its scary how rusty our skills can become and this has made me excited to be a developer again. I would suggest to anyone taking the course to follow the tutorials code by code - even though you can download the code, the live view was very easy to set up in VS and you'll likely learn more by making your own directory filled with folders per each video followed. And a nice code reference to look at from time to time.

I'm going to read Eloquent JavaScript after this tutorial. I don't normally rate video tutorials but Brad is excellent - the kind of dev you would be lucky to work alongside on projects with!

results.content: Boy is Brad fast. Coming from HTML and CSS with literally zero understanding of JS I found myself pausing the video a LOT just to grasp things. Now that I understand the syntax, - and Brad did an awesome job at explaining that - I realize he's actually going slow. The learning is intuitive, feels great and is always based on relevance and extrapolation of the subject's possibilities, so even learning the basics gets exciting. JS is no longer mumbo-jumbo to me and it took only a handful of classes for that, and I'm really excited about what this course is still about to teach me. Worth every single dime.

results.content: I'm an experienced Java/Kotlin developer who needed to brush up my javascript (especially ES6) as I last did web development in the early 2000s. Brad's course is really comprehensive with really good examples but he doesn't labour over the minutiae. I think this is a really good one-stop-shop before going on to look at React and Angular to ensure you have a really good grounding in javascript. (Also, it's super cheap for the amount of content you get.) The patterns stuff is great and so is the bonus stuff on webpack/babel

results.content:
Positives: 

This course is pretty extensive in terms of the number of topics covered.

Support provided for this course is pretty decent.

I like Brad's code along approach, because if you write even 10 lines of code just to test out a concept (and save it), then you are more likely to remember it and you can always come back to it for revisions.

Weaknesses:

Too many loose ends, too much googling and mdn browsing in a course i paid for.

Small errors in explanation here and there can lead to hours (in one case days) wasted on googling

Whats more, Brad very cunningly tiptoes past the topics he wouldn't or couldn't explain like closures. Yeah a JavaScript course without a mention of closures.

No word about apply, bind or call functions. 

He used filter function late in lecture 98 in a wrong manner which just by luck worked for the example he was working on. So cannot even expect the explanation there.

Incomplete coverage of the the spread operator.

For...of loop (without any introduction) was used for the first time in the lecture on sets in section 10.

In the last section, he just tells to download the webpack+babel setup from his GitHub profile without explaining how he created it.

EDIT: Now that i know more about webpack, the ES6 Modules didn't even require babel to work. ES6 Modules work with Webpack without Babel.  

The list is too long.

results.content:
I the course and it did take much longer than posted, obviously this is because you go front to back with all the code given and information shown to you throughout the course to gain a more solid understanding of the flow. One critique I would add is a slower breakdown of the independent smaller items spoken about throughout the course and minimal projects to see the breakdown in detail of specific actions given within tags or '.textContent' , '.parentElement' , etc. 

These were small areas that really took time to search in detail on google, stackoverflow, and other sites to gain a more detailed understanding of the actions or how they reference other specific items in the code iteself.

This course over all was a very helpful tool and I know I will be revisiting it regularly until I have a more firm grasp on the content and how to build projects using javascript.

results.content: This course is perfect in flow with properly aligned knowledge and projects. Projects are a huge part of this course and they cover all the variations possible. Brad is a very intellectual teacher he will teach you things in a very simplified way and I like how he stresses on proper usage of syntax in a very specific form so that it will be helpful in the real world. JavaScript pattern was a very good inclusion and project based on module pattern was the best according to me. In which you could learn the right way to code since nodejs is module based. I wish brad could include more practice projects that are similar to tracalorie. No videos reqire for that just show us what to make and give us the solution at the end. Overall this was the best course I could ever take on JavaScript. I will also Brad's React and MERN stack course.

results.content:
Honestly I had to stop this course roughly 30% in because his method of explaining was awful. There would be long winded explanations on how to target things in the Dom that would last 25 min however not once was "return" ever really explained in depth. 

Another example was he would write functions like 'function deleteItem(e) but never once explained what e meant in detail and what was happening. 

I would recommend this course to someone who already knows Javascript and wants to refresh concepts not to some one who is starting. You will have a lot of code written and not understand what have even written or how it's functioning. 

This is just my opinion however, good luck!

Brad Traversy by himself has probably taught more people how to code than any other single person on the planet at this point.

The course was really good. It contains a lot of material packed in a sequential manner. 
Only section where I felt that the course lacked a little bit was the design patterns section where the explanation was good but the application examples could have been better, since design patterns are really tricky to completely understand with a single example.

results.content:
This course is best for those guys who have zero knowledge on JavaScript and want to get your hands dirty.
Brad does a fabulous job in hand holding and make concepts easy to understand.
It's a well balanced course between theory and projects this was the aspect that attracted to me here.

If you're already seasoned developer then you might like to pick particular areas of the course.
If you're revising your JS skills for JS libraries or Framework then you'll have a good base to build.

Now, what wasn't great,
ES7 and beyond are missing
Vanilla JS course, no touch on DS or Algos using JS.
CSS Frameworks are used to build a quick UI.

I will edit my ratings once I complete it
Stay tuned.

results.content: I like that there are several full projects in this course. It lets you start typing JavaScript and practicing what you've learned. It's a good feeling to see the results of some cool projects that you finished coding. Some other cool gems in this course are the use of CSS frameworks like Materialize, Skeleton, and Bootswatch, when putting together the UI for the projects. The weather app project needs to be updated since the Weather Underground api is no more. The OpenWeather api website/docs aren't as easy to navigate as others, and can be confusing for complete beginners. Brad's a great teacher especially for beginners that have no experience whatsoever. His YouTube channel is an EXCELLENT resource/supplement as well. I like how in many of his videos he explains the simplest of things because they are things that true beginners with no experience would have known.  Overall, a great course for learning and putting into practice some JavaScript.

It is a good course although you always run into things where a bit more explanation would have been good. Many people complained about the CalTracker project. It was very complicated, yes. What would have been really great, and I asked a question about that, would have been an explanation of how to split this up into the MVC pattern. It was difficult to understand what was happening, also because of the scrolling up and down all the time.
Otherwise, I think it was what I expected: a walk through JS with projects to practice it, and that is very useful. Thanks Brad, and looking forward to other courses in the future.

results.content:
Pros:-
01) 'Sir' Brad is a great Teacher.
02) Most of the time is spent on practising stuff than just learning some textual information.
03) It's great that you can learn other web development skills from the same teacher(on Udemy and YouTube) than to just keep looking for everything on different platforms.

Cons:-
01) After the DOM lectures, it becomes difficult to understand the course, I mean we can understand the code but not a proper explanation is given, it becomes somewhat difficult to keep track of what's happening after DOM lectures. It will be better if concepts should be more clearly defined using good textual information(slides).
02) It would be better for Brad to start with only the new features of ES6 and properly explain that, and do a proper project, and then explain the old things in a separate section. Explaining everything from old to new JS in the same section, kinda make it difficult.

Tips:-
01) JavaScript is all about practice, so practice as much as you can.
02) Understand the concepts clearly on the internet to understand what is the actual use of each feature of JS.

results.content:
I found the course informative and and instructional. I received a lot of information about JavaScript properties, their uses and how they can be combined to produce useful blocks of code.

The introduction outlining many of the properties of JavaScript was a little overwhelming; the information cannot be sufficiently internalised until much practice with it has taken place. Therefore, I think a better strategy would have been to introduce and explain JavaScript properties as and when they are required during the projects; a similar approach was used when discussing design patterns.

The design of each project is very good, as each deals with an aspect of implementation that is currently being used in production, making the projects very relevant. It would have been helpful to use the new syntax of arrow functions as the course progressed, but I think converting the projects to use arrow functions would be a useful, personal challenge for learners. What I found especially useful is the utilisation of past projects to complete new ones; that is almost priceless.

I recommend this course to anyone wishing to gain field knowledge of pure JavaScript (and the recently added syntactic sugar in ES5 and ES6), but suggest that a good amount of time be devoted to actually learning what Brad has to offer.

results.content:
This course has all the basic information you need to learn JS. However, there is very little in terms of teaching going on. Essentially, Brad is good at presenting the information, but rarely or never takes a step back and lays out any connections between different concepts (such as why two similar things are different and equally needed) or even why certain concepts are so important and wide-reaching. My advice is take notes as Brad does his thing, noting down the concepts, and while watching google the concept and try to figure out the broader context. You will not find that in this course, which is instead focused on letting you see them in action - which is great, but does not inherently explain them on a level above "this is what this is/does".

TL;DR
On the one hand, a solid collection of information; on the other, requires a lot of inference.

results.content:
I've gone through 54% of the course and I've had to stop. The rating given is based on what I went through. The start of the course was nice, it was of course the easy stuff and Brad did a good job of showing some real world examples and real workings all the way up to the DOM section.

When I got to working with API (section 7). I understand why Brad decided to teach both the es5 and es6 methods. Cause it's nice to know where the syntax came from and what's going on underneath. However I feel the section wasn't given as much to explain in detail everything that is going on. Especially the es6 part of it all. 

I guess this is a personal thing, but learning one syntax and then moving on to the next so quickly and being told it's better than what you just learnt feels a little frustrating. Understandable, but frustrating.

I think Brad can explain things very well, but there are certain parts which feels like he forgets that we don't know what's going on his brain and what each line of code really means. And i'm not asking to be babysit throughout the course, but I feel there's a middle ground that wasn't achieved in some important sections. 

Thank you Brad for the course up until section 7 (i haven't gone past that, might do in the future once i get API stuff drilled in). Really helped with things I couldn't make sense of through websites like codecademy. Peace!

results.content:
Fantastic course! Coming into this course all I knew was HTML/CSS, and I had done a bit of programming in C and Python on a couple of other intro courses. I was an absolute JavaScript beginner when I started this course and I now feel like I'm a competent JavaScript developer! What more can you ask?

The learning curve is just right. There is a jump in difficulty between the fundamentals and then the practical projects, but the jump is required to take you to the next level. As with every programming course that I've done so far, you do have to do a bit of your own research and reading around the topic to fully understand any concepts that may confuse you. That is to be expected though as no instructor can hold your hand at every step as the course would be 100+ hrs long.

Brad is an excellent and down-to-earth teacher and I highly rate his tutorials. His Youtube channel, Traversy Media, is brilliant and i'll be enrolling in all his other Udemy courses to teach myself full-stack development in the aim of getting my first job in the industry. You can't go wrong with any of Brad's courses. Good luck to you all! ;)

results.content:
I was really looking forward to this course as I have seen a few of Brad's videos on youtube. Having taken a few JS courses already, I am familiar with concepts and understand the basics to some advanced topics.

Having said that, the course from Brad seemed very code along with no explanation, I feel a beginner would not understand any of the code unless they make a lot more effort to go out and search for it while pausing the video.

The course covers the basics and all the key title bullet points are there but the explanations that would give the student a greater understanding are unfortunately just not up to par with other JS-bootcamps out there.

My advice would be to take more time planning what is being covered and the order it is covered, then ensure that every single topic has a deep explanation as to WHAT it does, WHY it does it, and HOW it does it. With multiple scenarios in different apps or console tests etc.

Thanks

results.content:
I like Brad, his approach and his courses. This course covers a lot in a relatively short period. As a result, I don't think I have taken everything in and will need to revisit some sections as I put everything into practice.

I have many years worth of experience dabbling with JavaScript and JavaScript frameworks. I wanted to go back to basics and also to update myself with the newer standards; for this the course was great. However, I'm not sure the course is for absolutely everybody as I only just kept up at times.

There are some sections of the course where things have changed and you need to adapt the project to get it to work, such as WeatherJS where the chosen API is no longer available. However, for me, these were some of the best bits of the course as you are forced to work alone and use the principles you've just learnt to get things working rather than just copying what Brad is doing and fixing your typos.

The course is very thorough, and I like that everything is pure JS. I really learnt a lot about the language while completing the lectures.

If I had one major complaint it's that there are a lot of lectures where the JS language syntax and features are just listed off and shown, and this was often quite tedious, despite being very useful. I wish some of these features were demonstrated through very small projects or exercises, as it would have made these sections much easier to watch.

results.content:
I like how Brad really hammers down concepts by giving you a large amount of small practical projects. This made it interesting and allowed you to get plenty of practice with the concepts that were introduced. I noticed that most of the low ratings were due to the fact that he is not present in the Q&A. This didn't matter to me because 1) If I have further questions, I usually use a tool like google. In the real world, there is no Q&A, you need to be able to look up some stuff yourself.  2) Most of your questions have been answered by the  other students in the class OR  if you post a question in the Q&A, I'm sure you will get a response from another student in the class.  Another critique I saw in the low ratings are 'instructor makes mistakes'. Really?
Yes, Brad makes mistakes while typing on the fly. WE ALL DO!! And guess what, you need to be able to do what he does and figure out where the bug is. This is what he does, which I thought helped me figure out similar mistakes that I made.
So, if you are considering taking this course, I would say take it. It's one of the best JS courses on Udemy.

results.content:
The information Brad covers in these videos is very thorough. However, he has this annoying habit throughout the course of constantly dropping jargon and using terms that haven't been defined or explained yet, and then, to make matters worse, saying "You don't know anything about this, but I'll explain it later." If we don't know anything about it, why are you using the term?? And if you use the term, why don't you explain it? 

This is just lazy teaching, and the such heavy use of jargon creates an "in-crowd" and "out-crowd" environment in the classroom. If you really want to show off your teaching skills, explain your concepts a) without jargon, and b) in terms that ANYONE can understand, even someone who's never had a whit of programming before.

If you want to get a course and be confident you will come away from it a better developer then Brad is the guy! Love his YouTube stuff but he really goes in depth on the entire scope of the JavaScript language.

results.content:
Clear, simple and explained naturally. The pace lets you practically follow what he is explaining and if you encounter one section you already know and want to refresh, the way he speaks lets you up the speed and don't miss a thing. I recommend take all the courses of interest that this instructor offers (done that, 0 regrets).
Finishing the course was a long but fruitful journey, I started knowing a bit of js and now I feel with a much broader knowledge of understanding, more in my case after starting a node.js course and going "wtf?" so I had to rollback to js first.
Course is fun and engaging and although there is miss of a delete function in one of the videos by the end, is no biggie as it can be copied from the library or from the text you see in the video.
If you are unsure about taking this course with Brad, go to youtube, soak up his videos and I'm sure you'll be back here, enjoy!

results.content:
This is a very good beginners JS course mainly because Brad sticks to teaching you modern JS syntax which you will see in today's projects. I would recommend this course for people who are getting started before jumping into a JS framework.

The biggest problem with this course is Brad is not really responsive anymore and he doesn't go into details or explain enough at times. This will require you to either do a little more research (look for books on the topic and/or Google Search) but I did find that going to his youtube page he will go deeper in most of these areas.

Overall it was worth it and I am glad I took the time to complete this course.

results.content:
I'm gonna give 4 stars because I feel it would be unfair to give it any less, however I think there are quite a few important points to consider before diving into this course if you are an absolute beginner. My main criticism is that Brad (the instructor) rushes through the concepts while they are still being introduced in each section, and doesn't provide enough (if at all) examples or explanations but simply demonstrating how things are syntactically written in Javascript. It is no doubt our job as students to practice and research on our own beyond this and any course. However it's very discouraging to spend so much time and energy to finally understand whats been explained, only to move on to the next section and repeat this process again. For absolute beginners especially I'd recommend checking other videos/tutorials elsewhere before diving into the concepts that are introduced here. Make sure you check all Q&A as they are a great source of information!

Now that said, one of the things that I really like about Brad's videos are the projects, completely built from scratch and going through each line of code. This is a great exercise that shows you clearly how things are done (or can be done), and gives you enough practice to understand the tools at your disposal. If you've been paying attention you will be able to tell where Brad is intentionally doings things in a 'sloppy' way so that you can then go an improve it yourself. It's also a very complete courses, it covers quite a bit, and is by no means perfect but it is an excellent booster on your knowledge.
EDIT: After reviewing other courses' content I must say Brad really does cover a lot of material here, so even if as an introduction or to extend your knowledge this is already great. Another thing I forgot to mention is that in other courses I've taken from Brad, as well as his videos on YT, he does a great job explaining so they are worth exploring as well. Just for some reason here is a bit tough to follow bit don't let this review discourage you from diving in, it's just friendly advise and feedback for students and instructor :)

results.content:
Overall I thought the course was well laid out and I did learn a lot. I just wish more time was spent on deeper explanations of why things are being coded a certain way instead of just demoing what is being done.

Some of the exercises seem to be more of a demo. The instructor is just telling you what to write to achieve the end goal instead of explaining in detail what is happening and why. If you try to code along, you have to either slow the video a lot, or pause/play. In the end I felt as though I didn't actually learn from the particular exercise, I just wrote the code I was told to write.

Amazing course, I have enjoyed it a lot and I have learned a lot.
I really recommend it to those who want the learn vanilla javascript before frameworks. I definitely feel more confident now and I can't wait to attend another of Brad's courses.

There is only one thing that came to my mind and it is using:

let x = ....;
someArr.foreach( function(elem) {
x += someTextRepresentationOfElem;
};

I am a fan of functional programming and from my point of view using a reduce/fold operation on the array would be a little cleaner.
const x = someArr.reduce( (acc,elem) => acc + someTextRepresenationOfElem );

results.content:
Before taking this course, I highly recommend learning JavaScript.  This is not a course for the absolute beginner.  Hoping that it was, I was left with much confusion very early on.  

How Mr. Traversy "teaches", is through example and not by explanation.  There is a lot of "You can do this..." but hardly any "What this means..." Although very knowledgeable on the topic, he has a hard time knowing HOW to teach.  

The video dialogue seemed rushed and shot while he talked with hardly any structured learning script.  

This would most likely be a great course to take if you are transitioning from earlier versions of JavaScript and want to know the new changes in ES5.  

Thankfully for me, I have other courses that I have purchased from Udemy, which will actually teach me the core fundamentals in JavaScript.  Then, I will revisit this course as a review or a refresher.

results.content:
I'll preface my critique of this course by saying that anyone who puts as much effort into training material as Brad does deserved at least 3 stars.

Brad obviously knows javascript like the back of his hand. Unfortunately, I've had a hard time figuring out his target audience because he seems to waver a bit on the level at which he's presenting.

On the one hand, he describes how variables can be const while the content of const reference variables can be modified (which is a totally basic concept to anyone that's programmed in ANY language for more than a year).

On the other hand, he skips over detailed discussions of the differences between a NodeList and an HtmlList in the DOM. It's pretty easy to pick up the differences via context while watching him talk *around* these topics, but a targeted description of these differences is important, I would think, in this course.

He spends way too much time repeating similar concepts. For example, he shows how you can use offsetY to get the Y offset of the mouse in a mouse event, and then spends an *equal* amount of time showing you how you can use offsetX to obtain the X offset. That's ridiculous - you'd have to be a complete idiot to need the same level of discussion for the second of these after a detailed description of the first. I would have described and demonstrated offsetY and then mentioned you can do the same with offsetX and let it go.

This sort of thing happens time and time again in this course. Done correctly, this course could cover the same material at the same level in 1/3 to 1/2 of the video content. I can only assume he has a secondary goal in his presentations of content completeness, perhaps for the sake of the downloadable material, but this is not the right way to build course content. Content should build on concepts taught previously, rather than by assuming a blank slate at every bullet point.

If you are completely new to programming, you may be able to watch this course at 1.0x speed without falling asleep. If you've got any programming experience at all, I'd recommend 1.5x for the entire course. If you're a seasoned programmer wanting to learn javascript, the only remotely tolerable way is to watch the first couple of sections at 2.0x, and then slow down to 1.5x when he starts showing you the projects.

I'd recommend this course for the non-programmer wanting to learn about something he's heard about on the street - javascript - and is considering a career change. If you're patient and willing to watch at 2.0x speed, it's a VERY complete treatise on the topic.

results.content:
This course, as with all things Brad does, is thorough, comprehensive and well-paced. I learned a ton from building these projects. It may seem a little slow to start but that's because he's ensuring you not only know the ins-and-out of JavaScript but also why you would choose one way of accomplishing a task over another, which is very helpful.

My favorite part is when we get into JS Patterns because it really helped me understand what's actually happening when I'm using front-end JS frameworks (like React and Angular) .  

There is a 'delete posts' video missing right before the last video but the code for it can be found in the lecture downloads and the Q&A. I would highly recommend this course to anyone wanting to learn JavaScript more in-depth.

results.content:
Brad puts out some great content on YouTube, and I really enjoyed it to learn a lot of the basics of programming. However this course barely grazes JavaScript, and it feels more like you're just getting pushed along than really learning anything.

JavaScript concepts are extremely complex for anyone to understand, especially a first time learner. You get the sense Brad has forgottent that. He touches on every point he should, but he does it so quickly I get left behind his incredible level of knowledge on the subject. 

We built a couple interesting projects, but they're not aesthetically pleasing at all, and while I know this isn't a design or html and css course, I wouldn't show off any of these projects in a portfolio without a ton more work.

Worst of all, after completing the last project, Tracalorie, I was left with a sense of imposter syndrome. Yes I did the project line by line, yes I understand the overall structure and what I wrote if I look at it carefully again, but if anyone asked me to rebuild it, I would have no idea where to start. 

Overall, the course is not something I'd recommend to someone learning JavaScript for the first time. If, however, you are someone who wants to update their skills and already has a decent grasp of JavaScript, or are coming back to JavaScript after working with another language for a while, this might be a course that interests you.

results.content:
Overall this course was great. The instructor seems to really know his stuff, and all of the code examples/projects worked as described. 

Some of the drawbacks: There isn't an active Q/A community, so if you have a typo, or mess something u then, you're on your own! Also, there's a few points where I feel the instructor just does stuff and doesn't really explain it. I think this course would be 5-stars if the Q/A community was more vibrant, and if the instructor explained why he did things (especially near the end with the more complex topics). Lastly, I think it would help immensly if there were projects that the student had to complete first that helped them learn the material before the solution is given. Thanks!

results.content: I learned a lot from this course, and that's pretty much because Brad doesn't explain everything,  so you can research and go deeper on the course materials and investigate external resources. It might surprise you you can actually work your way to complete them by yourself.

results.content:
So far this is an incredibly well-done video series. I like how each session "starts from scratch", meaning that a faster way would be to "copy and paste" code from previous sessions, but that would not permit a new user to absorb the new material. As a newbie, there is certainly a lot of material to learn.
My only feedback for change would be to explain a little better the HTML classes. I have started to infer their meaning, but it is not clear where these classes come from, and how you know what names to use and what the possible options are .
results.content_html:
