results.content: For those of you that are trying to learn JavaScript, this is a great course paired along with freeCodeCamp as Brad covers a lot of the topics that freeCodeCamp doesn't cover or barely cover. Paired with the many projects Brad offers, this course really gives you good insight with how to use modern JavaScript in the real world. I also love how Brad often mentions industry standards for coding which is something that is rarely discussed online.  Brad also spends a lot of time going over most of the functions in JavaScript which could be useful for new users who are not aware of the many functions, although this section could be avoided if you have experience with JavaScript already. The only issue with this course is that it is really fast paced. Sometimes Brad adds new things to a project and doesn't explain in detail why he does it. This wasn't really problematic for me as I already had a strong foundation in JavaScript, but I could see a beginner struggling to understand why those pieces of code work.

Brad also spends a lot of time going over most of the functions in JavaScript which could be useful for new users who are not aware of the many functions, although this section could be avoided if you have experience with JavaScript already. The only issue with this course is that it is really fast paced. Sometimes Brad adds new things to a project and doesn't explain in detail why he does it. I don't think this is good enough for beginners. There's a lot of material you are expected to go through before you get to projects, and there is no way to memorize all that without exercise - which there is none of... until you get to projects. If you want to start learning JS better have a lot of additional materials because this course is not going to cut it.

On the bright side - the instructor is interesting, and explains things well... too bad he didn't include more exercises here, it could have been a really great course!

results.content:
I started this course with basic knowledge of JS (var, conditional statements, loops), and I was intimidated by intermediate and advanced concepts (callbacks, Promises, async, await, fetch). Never knew they were quite simple. After completing this course, I built few projects (News finder using Gradient API and GitLab- finder using Gitlab API) using fetch, which gave me the confidence to explore more about JS and learn new frameworks. Hands-on experience does help a lot.
If you want to get the basics right and learn the "behind the scenes" of any JS framework, this is the perfect course to start with.
results.content_html:

results.content:
Rarely do I give any review, but this time I simply find it obligatory. Brad explains Vanilla Javascript in a practical way, which is quite rare. Most of times, you find courses which teach you a simple theory without showing you how to use it effectively in real life.

Whatever your experience is or your goals are, a course of his is worth your time. Great value for price. If I have learnt a lot from it, so will you. 

Thank you, Brad. Hope to learn more from your next courses. Respect.

results.content: I am a really big fan of Traversy Media, I follow his Youtube videos religiously and loved his Materialize CSS course. So it really pains me to say that this course is awful for anybody learning the Javascript language for the first time. The only people who should buy this are people who are already familiar with Javascript and want to get up to date with es6 features. This course is not beginner friendly in the slightest, Brad just doesn't explain key concepts very well, to the point where I found myself looking up Youtube videos for every topic he covered. Brad introduces the very basics decently well, but it all fell apart at the object-oriented programming section, and it only went downhill from there. He would kind of explain each concept, then never explain it again whenever he used it in his code, which just led me to be completely confused and forced me to watch Youtube videos that are much better at explaining then he was. Brad really is a great instructor, and I will absolutely be buying another course from him, this specific course, however, was poorly taught when compared to the usually fantastic instruction that I normally get from him. Go somewhere else if you are a beginner, well worth a buy if you are experienced with javascript.

results.content: Brad is an excellent instructor and course designer ?. I greatly benefited from each lesson, which either reinforced what I have learned elsewhere, or provided clear instruction for new information. Brad also introduced me to a number of very useful development tools, as well as workflow methods. I strongly encourage those taking the course to do so in a linear way, beginning with the first lesson and working methodically through to the end. The last lesson uses material developed earlier in the course, so this approach is necessary if one wants to avoid frustration ?.

results.content:
This course is very streamlined, which is great, but there are SO many times where Brad will just go over the very basics of a concept and then go on to use it in a very complex way in the following example projects without slowing down at all to explain what's happening. This gets very frustrating, especially in the latter half of the course.
This course is advertised as being for everyone, but I strongly feel that this is NOT FOR BEGINNERS. I have multiple years of JS experience and I figured this would be a good way to refresh my skils, but even I am struggling here and there.
That's not even to mention that some of the projects are just out of date and can not be completed as shown (the Weather API project in particular).
I guess I would recommend this course, but definitely have some other tutorials on standby. You'd have to be VERY proficient starting out to really understand what's going on throughout the whole course.

UPDATE: After finishing the course, I feel glad that I took it. I still hold the opinion that there is a pretty ridiculous difficulty spike in the latter half of the course, but that doesn't really take away from all the things I've learned. Having to find workarounds for the few things in this course that are outdated has actually helped me understand what I was doing, so that's a plus. I think. Honestly, a beginner could absolutely get a lot from the first half of this course, so I would recommend that. 
Moving forward, I'm going to try a different instructor for the next technology I learn. I don't trust Brad to elaborate on anything too complex.

results.content:
Good walk through on what needed to be done for setup. Good examples on why these tools are useful. Pretty slow going in the first three sections, but that is to be expected.

I am an embedded software developer with almost 15 year of industry experience using C/C++ and C# languages. I would like to note that if you have a similar background, that the way he uses labels for functions could be made more clear. 
You can make a function like normal, then just use the function name. This looks much cleaner and makes it much easier to understand what is going on. I'm sure he touched on this in the very beginning, but when you are taking so much in, who remembers.

Also keep in mind that you are watching someone else code, who has many years of experience, and that his workflow is probably not similar to yours. 

Finally, understand that this tutorial was made X number of years ago, and some of the websites he links in his HTML files are no longer the same. Spent way too much time trying to figure what I did wrong, then finally took the link out of the resource files, and it looked just like his.

Half a star off for not being able to download all the resources as one compressed file with all the projects in there, or at the very least, one compressed file for each section with all the projects in there.

results.content: It is obvious that that instructor knows Javascript. Wonderful! Kudos all day to that. But when you're teaching, you have to be able to view through the lens of your audience or your target market. This is not a course that would set up a solid foundation for the beginner. I could research more, yes, but the whole intent of Udemy is convenience- hopeful one-stop with resources provided if there's no depth given. If I have to go outside of this course just to find out what's been talked about, then what's the use of investing in the course? Hm. His voice is not monotoned which is one of reasons I purchased the course. However, it's very, very rushed and the thoughts are not holistic. Rather it's a showing of something and a 'I'll come back to this later' throughout the whole course. Would be an awesome course if it was taught step by step with a holistic focus on each section topic at hand vs jumping all over the place. Yet, the same thing that annoys me about this class drives and fuels me. Causes me to challenge myself to learn it one way or another- with or without an instructor, but, everyone is not built that way. This course doesn't seem to be built for those seeking to know depth for what's being done and why. The instructor is very talented as I've saw some of his postings on youtube! Pleasant speaker. Could easily be one of the best courses and highest-selling if adjustments were made in the future. If it were not so, I wouldn't even post this review. Also, it's a constant mention in the reviews that the instructor doesn't reach back. Do better! That is all. Carry on. Go with God. C'est la vie! ^__^

results.content:
This course is an excellent material on modern JavaScript, and I'm glad it lived up to it's name. Brad walks through all the changes that made today's JS, but once the newly-introduced features are learned, he sticks to them. I really enjoyed working all the projects (I learned a lot about working with an API) and having to re-work some quite-consistent examples to make the translation from ES5 to ES6 made it more clear to me.
Another good thing about this course was that it helped me realize the concept of re-usability.

If there is one thing that kinda bothered me was Brad's style to end his videos rather abruptly. It's much said "bothered", I mainly noticed it. But I guess that's his style, since I watch his YouTube channel as well and I know he doesn't waste time on pampering.

Thank you, Brad Traversy!

results.content: This was a very good course.  The only think lacking was a more thorough explanation of design decisions when building the apps and an explanation of why you might use an arrow function in place of a normal function.  But that is a minor constructive criticism.

results.content:
For me one of the best courses i have ever taken. Its very in-depth and you learn everything you need, to write complex applications without a frontend framework. I want to develop a complex webgl application and after this course i think i know how to structure complex javascript code into modules and setup a proper architecture. But I have to say, that I have a lot of previous experience in other languages. For complete beginners the pace may be sometimes a bit fast I think. In some lectures I had often to pause, to program along and understand what the teacher is doing. He types fast and explains the same time. To get a better impression of the teacher you can take a look on the Traversy Media youtube channel. There is even a free javascript beginner course, where you can learn the basics, before dive deeper in js with this course. 
Besides these points the course worked perfect for me and I learned more than I expected. Five Stars !

I want to develop a complex webgl application and after this course i think i know how to structure complex javascript code into modules and setup a proper architecture. But I have to say, that I have a lot of previous experience in other languages. For complete beginners the pace may be sometimes a bit fast I think. In some lectures I had often to pause, to program along and understand what the teacher is doing. He types fast and explains the same time. To get a better impression of the teacher you can take a look on the Traversy Media youtube channel. There is even a free javascript beginner course, where you can learn the basics, before dive deeper in js with this course.
Besides these points the course worked perfect for me and I learned more than I expected. Five Stars !

results.content: Up to date with Javascript 2015/ES6 on the get go. Just on the topic of variables, Brad made the right call to teach ES5 and ES6 on the get go instead of teaching ES5 first then ES6 after you've completed ES5. Designing the course this way took away the hanging question, "What's this ES6?". It's way more efficient! It's well-designed. ES6 is not an after-thought or a late addition. I think Brad's brand of teaching is about being up to date and efficient.

results.content: Halfway trough this course and as a first time lurker in JavaScript and programming I can say that this course is good...BUT. Brad simplifies things retaining the essence of the concept. This is fine but you won't gain deep understanding. The way I go about it is after Brad explains something I do not understand completely , I go to some external documentation on the suject and try to comprehend the material.Its not easy but when I go back again to Brad's explanation I can make connections more easily bacause of his direct, more "simple" explanation. But you wont get far but being satisfied with only the hood. Go and see what's under the hood when Brad doesnt go, because it would take 2-3x the # of hours in this course for him to do so.And that's how long the course should go when you revisit and study deeply. So how you go about it matters too. Also redo the projects by yourself, and after a few days go again to them to deepen the the foundations of your understanding and gain context for future projects. I believe that going through one Javascript course that is 10 hour and it takes you 40, is better than just looking through 4 diffrent courses that are 10 hours.

results.content:
This course was a life saver!
I am an experienced developer, working for decades with C\C++ and C#. I been tasked with doing a node.js project, and was totally confused because things are quite different there from the way they are in the more 'traditional' programming world that I know. I bought some books but none gave me the whole picture. This course saved me and probably saved my career. In one setence: It was everything you need. nothing you don't. everything that I hoped for, in a very economical format. Great work!!

results.content:
This is a pretty good course, but some of the technology is already outdated, or there are new issues that make following the examples impossible. For example, in lecture 70, we use JSONPlaceholder the whole time to create functions but there is a problem with CORS that may be new since he made the lectures. It makes it impossible and very frustrating to get through.

He explains everything with a visual example in addition to what he's saying. So I can practice everything that he's doing and make sure it's matching up visually.

results.content:
If you're looking for a practical no-nonsense course on vanilla javascript, then I'd recommend this one. The course gets gradually more complex and you get to build mini projects along the way. So do not worry if it's "too basic" at first, it picks up later.

In the end, I learned more about how to work with DOM and APIs, have a better understanding of javascript frameworks and there was a mini library project which I enjoyed a lot. Thanks!
results.content_html:

results.content: Before starting this course my only experience with js was from going through the freecodecamp js section. This course has elevated my understanding of the language by showing how to apply these concepts to some real world applications. I felt the teaching method was clear and organized and wasn't a struggle to follow along. Although I did get stuck many times, the mistakes were often small syntax errors(fml). There were a few times where I think some background theory would have been useful(ie. closures) or where I wish the pace would have been a bit slower and easier to follow(but I guess that's what playback speed is for). Just my two cents. I'll definitely be referring back to this course as I progress. Overall great course. Also, thank you to the helpers. Cheers!

The content covered is very good, although I feel that merely repeating some of the things that we do in the class over and over again is not necessarily helping me learn all the little things. 

ex. when to use a querySelector over a getElementById
ex. values like value, textContent, and innerHTML

It would be nice to have some projects that give us a list of functions we may find useful and let us try to do the project before watching the video.

Amazing like all of Brad's courses. It really helps to have some prior programming experience but even if you don't the extra challenge will really teach you a lot as long as you work through all the troubles you go through. results.content: Judging by the reviews before taking this course, I really thought this one would be different than others I've taken. I learned some things during the beginning lectures, but after this first project, I'm disappointed yet again. He just speeds through this very first project, saying what he's doing but not really explaining why. Even the ULs and UIs should be broken down and explained one by one. I'm not new to HTML but I'm struggling to grasp an abstract concept here because he doesn't break it down to explain WHY we're using ULs and LIs to begin with, or WHY we add an anchor for the delete button. He gets it so well that it's as though he can't imagine that everything isn't already obvious to the learner. He says to use the class "fa fa-remove," which happens to not be working for me (no icon). A quick Google search informed me that this is apparently not unusual with Font Awesome. But I, like other users, wondered what the hell "fa" referred to. Since he didn't explain that it was related to Font Awesome, a newbie could think it was some built-in HTML feature, or maybe something new in HTML5 which adds an icon - who knows? It appears to be impossible to find a good programmer who is also a good teacher, at least during the projects themselves.

results.content:
I've just finished the course and I don't have a single complaint about it. I believe Brad covered all the important topics, his explanations were clear to me, there was just enough practice, I also appreciated that he did not spend too much time explaining some trivial matters. Plus, he sounds very well at x1.25 ratio, which is not very common. So I could comfortably listen to his lectures at x1.25, and switch to x1 when I had to code along with him. Besides that, he seems to be a very nice guy. 
I feel I am ready for his React course now.

results.content: REVELATORY! This moves me beyond simple coding - to actually start programming in JS (not the same thing at all...!!!). Also, Brad's frequent side-by-side examples of JS/ ES6 code give me a better idea of what's happening 'under the hood.' Last, but not least, Brad's sometimes 'water-cooler' style's given me a whole bag of unexpected new tools & resources.  Anyway, I've been refactoring bits of my own projects as I've moved through the course - and walk away re-imagining their core structure in new (and considerably more elegant!) ways. Lots to do next! Couldn't ask for more.  Many thanks Brad!

results.content: I struggled learning Javascript coming from a career with no programming skills needed or experience. I tried other videos and online courses and to me, it seemed like they were made from the perspective that people had previous programming experience and wanted to learn how to program with Javascript. The focus was mainly on just how to write functions, arrays, and objects and not seeing any results of this outside of logging things on a console. These lessons for the first time showed me how JS can manipulate the DOM, methods for targeting HTML in a webpage, creating OOP, modules, patterns, and lots more so I finally could see what JS was doing when related to working on webpages for front-end work. The small projects are super helpful, and helped me to really understand the language while both coming together and in the final product. I will definitely be revisiting these videos for practice and test how much more I can do independently as I progress.

results.content: The learning curve for a beginner in this course starts off very manageable, Brad knows how to ease someone into programming better than anyone I've found on the internet.  The learning curve gets steeper as the course progresses, primarily in the HTTP request/Fetch API project and last full-stack post project. That said, I feel like I have a high-level grasp on most JS concepts after finishing this course. If you're new to web development and programming I would highly suggest checking out Brad's YouTube channel and look into some of his courses on Udemy.  You get short form content on YouTube for free and if you want to build on that knowledge, his Udemy courses are more comprehensive and follow the structure of a class.

results.content:
Clearly Brad is a good coder, however I don’t think his teaching methods are effective as some of the other courses.

It feels like there is a lot less structure and planning within the lessons. It feels like he's winging it a lot of the time.

You’ll hear Brad often say things like:

“Hopefully this works…”

“You will never really need to use this but…”

“Normally you wouldn’t do it this way but…”

“I know I didn’t explain it in the best way, but…”

This gets frustrating and confusing.

Another gripe is that he often only explains the concept he is trying to teach at the end of lesson, which makes it difficult to follow.

It really feels like I’m watching Brad demonstrate his abilities during a technical interview for a programming job.

results.content:
Another excellent Traversy course!  I've done three now, and have a couple more in my plans.  Some thoughts on this one...
- I like how Brad runs tests as we build.  This shows us the progression of the build process, and gets us in the habit of progressive building.
- Although the course does take JS from the very beginning, the description should state more strongly that experience with a CSS framework could be helpful.  The course bounces between materialize, bootstrap and skeleton frameworks - which I liked.  But, from the comments, some people were struggling with the use of CSS frameworks.
- Sandbox suggestion for students: download and save each of the project files into ONE containing folder.  Preface their file name with the lecture number.  Make your notes as comments in each file.  In VS Code: open the containing folder as a project.  This way you'll be able to use VS Code search for any particular keyword across all course files.
- Everyone learns differently.  I learn better by editing rather than typing.  For each lecture I keep the completed project file open in VS Code.  As I follow along with the video, I'll edit each file comments to take my notes, and play with the existing file to learn more.  Sometime I add features to learn more.  For me this is better than typing all the code.

Thanks Brad!
results.content_html:

The course bounces between materialize, bootstrap and skeleton frameworks - which I liked. But, from the comments, some people were struggling with the use of CSS frameworks.

results.content:
This is a code-along course. If you're trying to learn from beginner you won't learn anything from this course. Everything is handed to you and you are not required to think for yourself. How are you supposed to learn how to code when you're not expected to code? It's like riding a bicycle but never removing the training wheels. 

I got over a quarter of the way through and I'm still just sitting here watching Brad code while I do...nothing? I understand watching through the fundamentals. I've watched through the basics of JS before in other courses, so that section wasn't too bad since it was just reviewing info for me. But I expected the Projects sections to have actual projects. Not just more of me watching someone else code. 

I skipped ahead and audited a few other lessons to see if they were the same and its ALL just watching Brad code.

If you're just looking for review or looking to sharpen your skills with ES6, you might enjoy this course. But for people who are actually trying to learn, this course is terrible. 

I intended to give 1 star. But when I was watching these courses my parakeets would always start chirping happily at the sound of Brad's voice, so I added a star for that.

results.content: Brad does a great job showing you how to code with lots of relevant examples in his content. However, where he could do better is explaining some of the underlying reasons for why a code does what it does. For beginners I would recommend taking a course that teaches Javascript fundamentals before returning to this one for more hands-on practice. Otherwise, be prepared to supplement your learning with lots of external resources to really understand what is happening.

results.content: I just finished the course! I also took Brad's HTML/CSS course. Ian both, I have been impressed by the level of breadth and depth that he packs into his courses. The content level is just at the right level for me, coming from a python background, with some C++ and Java under my belt (though none in a work setting). The projects are great for seeing things in action and are really the practical aspect of the course that you learn from. I feel very confident about my Js skills, and my next step is to work on some personal projects in which I incorporate the js I learned here. Afterwards, I'll be starting his REACT course, and soon after, his Django course. Thanks again Brad, you're the best!
results.content_html: I just finished the course! I also took Brad's HTML/CSS course. Ian both, I have been impressed by the level of breadth and depth that he packs into his courses. The content level is just at the right level for me, coming from a python background, with some C++ and Java under my belt (though none in a work setting). The projects are great for seeing things in action and are really the practical aspect of the course that you learn from. I feel very confident about my Js skills, and my next step is to work on some personal projects in which I incorporate the js I learned here. results.content:
I really don't believe this course is up to Brad's standards. The material provided is good, but is not updated. I found myself going to the Q&A section in every lecture to figure out details about the lecture (why it doesn't work, how to make it work etc).

Fortunately, the Q&A section is very helpful, and all the questions get answered to. I never had to ask a question myself, as someone else had already asked and been answered to.

Later in the course, Brad doesn't really dive into explanations, and just shows what something is.

Overall, I think this is a good course, but it could really use an update in the later sections. I chose Brad's course over many others' because I follow his YT and like his content, but this course did not meet my expectations.

results.content: Except for the tracalorie course module,  gone through this entire course.  I have no previous experience in programming, and .js is the first  programming language  I have attempted to learn and understand.  And for a beginner , who got introduced to the world of computer programming thru this course,  it becomes a bit tiring after the DOM Manipulation section  of the course. Nevertheless  I could understand the basics of  .js which  Shri. Brad Traversy  ( I too tend to spell it like Travesty)  had explained  in simple terms. But  after the DOM manipulation section, he goes too fast, maybe to cover more topics  to make this course  very comprehensive. Though the student is likely to understand what he is trying to explain, still the code and coding becomes overwhelming in the later half of this course.  Maybe it  would  help immensely , if some tips about  overcoming this situation , ie lightening the course in the second   half  is thought of. Maybe a real world example of   integration of front and back-ends, of posting data into a server with SQL or NoSQL data-structure, would have given the student a better understanding of how all these work together, which will encourage him to learn more, especially the difficult  parts.  Further wish that a quiz about the subject matter being covered  must have been provided to test the students learning and understanding and to reassure the student of his/her progress.   I am sure, Brad with his experience as a tutor/trainer  will be taking note of all these points , because I sincerely believe, he has the interests and well-being of this students/learners -and that includes the beginners who are taking the first step into the world of coding -upper-most in his mind. Thank you Brad, for this wonderful course and for all those free-vids on the YouTube.

results.content: The course is great, amount of material cover is huge, but what i missed is modern way of teaching. What I mean by that: the entire course is based on the method 'watch what i am doing and replicate'. That the way of learning that we know from school. Challenges and homework seems like more modern and better (in efficiency sense) way. Huuuuge plus for help in QA section, without Will's help I would never be able to finish the course. Its been hell of a fun of doing that and its scary as hell how much is to learn to be able to actually get a job. I hope that one day I will be able to help others with knowledge as I have been helped.

results.content: About the teacher: What I like the most is how straightforward, sharp and relaxed Brad is. I get easily annoyed watching people talk excessively about themselves or with strong accents that are hard to keep up with. You’re not going to find this on this course. ? About the course per se: I’m a beginner on JS so I naturally tend to find every little info useful (can’t tell if an advanced user would think so too), but I believe most would agree that there’s no BS in the lessons. Brad is clear, accurate and succinct - traits that I really appreciate. ?

results.content:
This was an excellent course. Just completed it. Hands down the most useful course I've done in five years (off and on) of self-learning web development. Worked through every step, and did some exploration along the way, expanding on some of the exercises.

The pace was great - I found that watching the basics at 1.5x and the remainder at 1.25x speed was ideal for me, though I did also stop and rewind a number of times through more complex sections.

I feel I now truly grok some of the fundamentals, and I feel comfortable with functional JavaScript in a way I never have before. In short, I am truly much better equipped to create what I want to create. Thank you for making such a great course, Brad! Thank you for the example of what a practical course looks and feels like.

results.content:
I think if you are brand new to coding this class moves to fast (because each of the lectures is just "look at this command and now look at this command)    It explains the "what" but not "how" and "why".

It also teaches absolute beginners bad coding practices (LOTS of code duplication )

For an experienced developer who is trying understand the nuts and bolts about javascript - after going through the first four sections - I have not learned anything I was looking to learn...such as What is the event loop and how does it work, How does this work in javascript.

I'm not sure who this course should be aimed at but sadly I won't be finishing it.

results.content:
Great job, Brad!!! I've taken your WordPress and Bootstrap 4 courses and sought you out to learn the other languages you teach and this class did not disappoint! 

I particularly appreciated your explaining things as you went along and continually reinforcing them. I first took up learning Javascript in 2015 and went off to other technologies because the books I had gave me no practice and I never was able to fully grasp the language and *how it worked*, but this course helped me to finally "get" JavaScript and I am now ready to move on to learning TypeScript in preparation for Angular. I've purchased your course and have it queued up and ready for when I complete this course. 

Thank you for such a solid class!

New to programming, starting off bad with the jargon.

After going through 25% of the course, I still feel like I'm just coding along. The explanations and reasonings behind actions taken in the lecture are completely lacking. Again, I am a newbie to this stuff, and I feel like suddenly the class is picking up, and I feel like I missed several hours' worth of lectures. The jargon is getting worse, and too many of the "we'll talk about this later" stuff keeps going un-covered.

I feel like this class isn't for beginners, but rather is for relatively experienced people who have programmed before.

results.content:
Hi to all reading :)

I took this course after following Brad for a few months on Youtube, where he produces high quality informational content for people who may be less fortunate that I am. Go check him out! As I say, I took this course blindly, but knowing Brad wouldn't put anything but 110% into it. And thus far am glad I have, I am refreshing basic knowledge (I am a noob at coding), but Brad helps by explaining every step clearly and precise, even if the code at that specific point in the video doesn't make sense, he later goes back and explains it in full.  Brad style is very mellow, allowing a student like me to just keep watching one after another without any hesitation, even with more sophisticated code, Brad will still take his time to explain the function and reasoning behind it. 11/10 from me. Keep up the good work Brad.

results.content:
UPDATE TO PREVIOUS UPDATE: I went through this course a second time, after having taken a couple of VueJS courses and recognizing that my fundamental JavaScript skills were still not entirely up-to-snuff. Maybe I'm just dense, but the second time through (and I went all the way through it, every lesson) and it all made so much more sense. Brad really is an outstanding instructor and if you're looking to deepen your understanding of core JavaScript concepts, this is the one you want. Really, really good.

UPDATED REVIEW: As noted below, I deducted a half-star because there was a video clearly missing, but since that time Brad has updated the course and included the missing lesson. So, I "undeducted" my deduction!

Brad is a well-versed instructor who really understands the course material and is able to convey it well. While the course is called "Modern Javascript from the Beginning," it isn't a beginner's course. Having read a few Javascript books and taken a couple of other Javascript courses, I had a basis for understanding certain topics that Brad covered rather quickly. This course is best suited for the person who already has some background in Javascript, but who wants to get their feet wet in ES6.

Deducted a half-star because there's clearly a missing video, between 116 & 117, on a delete function in the final project. Since the course files are provided, the missing code is available, so by the time you reach that point in the course, you should be able to either work it out yourself, or use the supplied code to insert it in the proper place in your own files.

Recommended course.

results.content:
Great course! Highly recommended to anybody in web development. The idea of learning pure JavaScript without depending on a framework is just awesome.

Brad is a great instructor. He is engaging, easy to understand, and he speaks in a natural and casual way. He clearly knows his stuff and the lectures is well prepared and organized. The pace is relatively fast which is good.

The course starts out by explaining the absolute basics of JavaScript and move on from there. The progression in the course builds on what has been learned in the previous lectures and there's a lot of much more advanced stuff later in the course. The mini projects works really well to show how the different things can be put into use in a real application.

I knew some JavaScript already before I started the course but I really learned a lot. After finishing the course I feel I have a much more solid knowledge of everything.

results.content:
This is an excellent course!

I've been involved in development for many years, but mainly on the server-side. JavaScript always seemed a bit mystical to me and I always 'muddled' my way through without really every understanding everything I was doing.

Brad takes a solid methodical approach to explaining core concepts (useful to beginners and more experienced folks alike), and then builds on this incrementally during the following modules. Everything comes together really nicely, and I now feel like I have a sold grasp of JavaScript and understand so many things that I didn't before.

The course is pretty long, but so comprehensive and done at a nice pace. Kudos to Brad for putting this together, it's one of the best courses I've done.

results.content:
Brad has excellent presentation skills and is a skilled instructor! I wish, though, there were more section exercises/projects. Considering all this, I'd rate the course 5 stars for the instructor, 1 star for lack of practice exercises and projects, which averages to 3 stars.

I'm 3 hours into the course and it's been all lecture and demos, and not a single exercise or project to complete. It looks like the first exercise/project is after another 2+ hours of lecture. So I'll be 5 hours in before the first exercise/project. 

Most courses I've taken on Udemy have at least one exercise or project per section. Frequently, you are building a course project, where the exercises/projects in each section are the building blocks to finish a bigger course project. Or they give you the skillset/coding practice to finish a bigger course project.

Instead he talks about one programming construct, demos it, and then moves on to the next concept. It's hard, if not impossible, to both follow the lecture and absorb the material, as well as follow along/key in as he demos as he moves quite quickly. Even if you can follow along, you're practicing abstract concepts with nothing to bring them together. 

As I say, I wish there were section exercises and projects from the beginning of the course that we students could complete at our own pace that would allow us to practice coding, and bring the concepts together to reinforce the material he presents.

results.content:
I'm not a huge fan of Brad Traversy...at least not as a teacher of web development.  I watch his YT channel from time to time, but I don't like the way he teaches.  This is MY OPINION and I'm sticking with it.  you, naturally, are entitled to your own opinion.  Obviously, he appears to be very successful as a web dev, he has a large YT following, and while he may not be the most popular instructor on Udemy, quite a few people have purchased his courses.  

An aspiring web developer can definitely learn from Brad, but there are some things about the way he teaches that make parts of his course boring and difficult to follow.  

I don't like how he reviews code or copies and pastes sections of code by just saying "I'm going to change THIS to newVarialbe"  or "I'm going to copy THIS and put it HERE".  Personally, this makes it hard to follow what he's doing and where he is doing it at.  I often need to scrub back and forth multiple times in the video to find exactly what line/section of code he's referring to. 

He's a decent teacher, but I am also not a big fan of him reviewing new concepts and writing code for 10 minutes demonstrating functions, loops, and code and saying "you don't have to understand any of this yet, but we'll need it in the upcoming project". Personally, I find it easier to learn when an instructor introduces 1 or 2 concepts, then slowly adds more detail while building the project or writes 1 version of the project, then adds complexity/features after the "basic version" is completed.  

I don't learn well when somebody throws a dozen new things at me in 10 minutes, then expects me to remember to use them over the next 30-60 minutes of "class" just because he says "remember how we initialized this variable and needed to use this parser to convert this data file to an array?"   

my review of Brad Traversy's Modern Javascript course is mostly a matter of "a difference in my learning style vs his teaching style".  I'm about halfway through the course.  I understand it, I intend to finish it, but I wish I had chosen an instructor that had a teaching style that worked better for me.

results.content: It's nice that you show the live changes of the website while coding. I think It can be more useful if you can show how each API changes the tree DOM to help us understand better what each api does internally. For example, I think there are some similarities between using appendChild() and using innerHTML. They both add a new element to a specific node but they have quite different effects. I come from a C.S background, so I might be a little too careful with this.

results.content: All of the material seems up-to-date, I haven't encountered any errors in the content so far (everything taught seems to work as demonstrated when I test it), and he really does cover everything, from the big to the small. Most importantly for me, he doesn't use a bunch of tools that are foreign to beginners or tech-jargon we aren't going to understand. There's only been one video out of the entire course so far that I thought could've been better explained, and that was the scope differences between let, var, and const. (I had studied them from different sources beforehand, so it didn't impact my experience much). This course was money well spent, in my opinion. I would buy courses from this guy again. UPDATE: I bought more courses (the HTML and CSS).

results.content:
Overall a good course, would recommend it to anyone who wants to learn more about web development using vanilla JavaScript. Brad is obviously a very experienced developer, and I've gone on to follow his YouTube channel as well, which is also a useful resource for aspiring devs.

I have now completed six javascript courses on Udemy so I can speak to their comparisons. This course, more than the others on javascript, involves a lot of DOM manipulation.   Additionally,  you will get in-depth experience in using asynchronous programming.  Even in parts that overlapped with previous courses, Brad found something that I had not learned.  You mostly learn by doing projects in this course which attracted me to this course in the first place.

Brad is very experienced and it shows in his presentations.

results.content:
I've just finished the course.
This is my second course with Brad and he's great!

The reason I've went with 4 stars instead of 5 is purely explanation-based. There have been multiple occasions where I've sat there thinking "So why am I doing this? Why this block of code? ", which can be very frustrating.

What's helped with that however is the community within the Q&A section, as someone has likely felt the same way, posting a question and more knowledgeable developers have answered.

I can imagine those with programming experience will adapt nicely to this course. However absolute beginners such as myself, may have their struggles. With that being said however, the struggles with errors & all sorts have been beneficial. It's then on you to solve what's wrong and I can only imagine that's beneficial going forward in your development career.

So I do recommend this course. If you're done your bit of programming beforehand, I can imagine you'll fly through it. If you're a beginner, by all means go for it but expect to hit a few hurdles along the way.

Worth every penny, do not hesitate to buy.

results.content:
Overall, this is a really good course covering all the bases of pure javascript. There are a few spots where Brad either gives slightly inaccurate info or only glosses over a concept, so make sure to read through all the Q&A for each lesson, as other students have filled in the blanks nicely. 

Also this course is not regularly updated and the API used for the weather app has been discontinued. Not a huge deal because again the other students have provided an alternative that works nicely.

Only rated 4 stars because of the lack of updating/followup from the instructor after initially posting the course, but it was definitely still worth taking.

results.content:
Very engaging instructor. I've watched many of his Youtube videos before buying this course on Udemy.

Course is well-paced, though I'd watch at 1.5x most of the time.
Good details for both beginners and those who want to upgrade to new ES2015+ like me.

The section on Patterns could use a bit more explanations as a whole and for each of the pattern. 

The projects could also have used a bit more debugging, less repetitions of code and included a few more features like generators, symbols...

All in all, I'd recommend this course.

results.content:
Brad is hands-down the best programming instructor on Udemy.  His simple examples really demonstrate the workings of JS.  I like the way he APPROACHES a difficult subject, building and exercising the code as he goes which makes it understandable.  I made copious notes.  This will be my JS Bible. 

You might consider a combined React, Angular and Vue.js course just so we could put our toes in the water and decide which one we want to concentrate on.  I see that you have Angular and now React covered.  I hope the Vuel.js is coming along!  I want to build some serious and original apps. My problem is that there are so many frameworks and I don't have years to learn them all.  I would like to choose intelligently and an overview course with deep dive courses would help.

The only criticism I have would be to perhaps have some pre-lecture files so that we don't have to watch you type as much.  Of course, dwell on new constructs but if we watched you type something very similar before, just copy and paste it in and perhaps review the code functionality verbally.  This is a small criticism.  This course is the best I've ever seen.  You have a real talent for teaching.

results.content:
Two of the projects in this course are quite out of date.  One is completely unworkable as it involves a discontinued api.  This is extremely frustrating as these could be valuable sections.

On top of that the instructor does NOT answer questions.  I have been working through the videos over a one month + period and have not seen him answer a single students question.

If you already know a programming language and can find your way around google this doesn't matter so much.  But if this is your first language DO NOT go with this course.

The section on webpack and babel is less than useless.

I'd suggest finding a course with a responsive instructor.

However, the rest of the course it's almost perfect. Brad is a great teacher and he explains things crystal clear. His English is very clear too. I'm from Spain and I have no problems at all to understand everything he says (and I didn't use subtitles). I highly recommend this course to anyone who is interested in going deeper in JavaScript. Thanks for your work, Brad!

results.content:
Nothing is explained in this course. It's just following along as Brad types up some code. You're not actually being "taught" anything, you simply just copy what Brad types without understanding any of it.

He doesn't go back over and explain the code he just typed. It's all just "OK so now I'll add a fetch then we'll wrap the fetch in a promise and now we'll add in a catch with a callback to our prototype and voila ... here's our working app! Now moving on ... ". 

The section on patterns is absolutely useless. You can skip that section entirely as Brad doesn't explain any of it.

He also doesn't participate in the Q&A section so if you get stuck (which you will every 2 minutes), all you can do is spend time googling for the answer or hope some other student has figured it out and is kind enough to reply.

Brad, if you're reading this then next time you release a course how about you actually try explaining the code. Either explain it as you're typing, or when you're finished go back over the code and explain how it works step-by-step. Simply typing out the code doesn't teach us anything.

I'm gettting a refund. This course is terrible.

results.content:
I'm not ging to lie , at first I hated this damn course. lol I felt that brad was talking way to fast , and it seemed that he was doing the projects and i was just copying his code. He teaches you a lot of good information , thats the only reason i come back to this course after buying a couple more. You just have to learn how to learn. 

For example my learning strategy is i watch like 20 seconds of the video. After that i pause it and replicate the exact same thing he's doing. After i replicate i comment the shit out of it , and try to dissect everything that is going on in that function or whatever.  If i dont understand somthing i rewatch the 20 seconds , if i still dont know i look on youtiube, or stack overflow. And if that doesnt work i looked through the question asked by peers.

I bought this course thinking i was going to learn everything just by watching the videos and following along. But that is not the case. It takes time. There are times where I watch a 20 min video and it takes me 2 hours to really understand his thought process, and understand why everything works. And i still feel lost but i know more than i knew yesterday and thats all that matters.

results.content: Brad does an awesome job of making the course fun and exciting, using real world projects, and applications to demonstrate the concepts. This course to me was about Javascript in action, at the end I am now able to build my own applications without having to rely on following a video, also I am much more prepared to go into front end libraries like React, now that I understand the "workings" of front end libraries. To compliment this course I am also taking several other courses that go more into the theory and understanding side of Javascript, as both aspects are equally important!

Again quality content from Brad! The first couple of sections are the very basics, but from there it gets a bit more difficult while still explaining the functionalities and giving you really good examples in projects. 

I really like the way the instructor (Brad) keeps the videos short. I hope that in the future he will keep the length at less than about 7-8mins. During that time Brad is able to share so much information that it might be a bit too much if the videos were any longer. The tone of the videos is very relaxed, but not boring (unless you already know this stuff.)

I believe there is something for everyone in this course! The beginning might be a bit too easy if you are familiar with JS, but if you take a look at the schedule I´m sure you´ll see plenty of interesting consepts! 5 STARS!

results.content:
I have taken other JavaScript courses from various platforms.  I a beginner when it comes to learning JavaScript, but when I am learning courses I take note on which teacher/resources are good or not. 

I would say the instructor knows his JavaScript knowledge but how he is teaching the course is somewhat all over the board. 

He talks about creating variables (let, const, etc..) but all of a sudden he get's into arrays and objects out of nowhere. He is teaching the basics of declaring and assigning variables (which is great from a beginners stand point), but if one is teaching one area of variables, then only stick to that subject. Then after discussing the intro of creating variables, then introduce arrays and objects on it's own section, not just mentioning it then just keep moving on. 

This is a huge pet peeve of my when I am critiquing developer's who can teach coding or not. I realize there are quite a few developers who been coding for years and when they teach, they don't structure/organize the courses in a way that seems to be transparent. Teachers who would talk about one subject, but then talk about a different subject without explaining what it is, I hate that!!

results.content:
This is NOT a BEGINNER'S COURSE!! It's more for an experienced web developer who wants to increase his/her's skillset by building web apps using pure JavaScript (no JQuery). 

The instructor mentions this. I didn't understand what he meant by this until I did additional research and I went through the majority of the course. 

If you're a complete beginner like me to JavaScript you will get lost. I recommend a book like "A Smarter Way to Learn JavaScript" to get started from scratch. 

I'm still giving the course 4.5 stars. Because I learned some new syntax related to ES6. Also, picked up some things related to structuring a project. And overall have a better understanding of web applications in general.
results.content_html:

results.content: This class is perfect for someone who is already familiar with the basics in another language. The class would easily be double in duration, if Brad went deeper into the explanation of things such as which "variables" are arguments and which are properties of an object while assigning the value of one to the other, and certain things like that. Naming them entirely the same may be confusing to new coders. But besides this, it seems to be a perfect course. The projects are great ways to apply these newly learned skills in real world applications as they even teach you more all the while. In other words, money well spent.

results.content: I did a 3 month accelerated full-stack development course at a reputable college and got a certificate in JavaScript. However, because we were flying through the course and cramming so much information about this language and many others it was nearly impossible to retain it all. I purchased this course to help keep my mind fresh for the interviews and have a different instructors view on the language. This instructor is incredible. He's covered in much more detail how and why parts of the language work the way it does and provided more information than I was able to get in my hands-on course. It's extremely important for new programmers to practice everything outside tutorials and he provides the material for you to practice with. It's also an excellent option for someone to have in order to exercise their brain after school (and you don't have to spend thousands to do it).

results.content:
In other courses I've taken that Brad Traversy has produced, he has answered questions on the Q & A forum.  He is noticeably absent on the forum, which is a huge disappointment.  If he is unable to answer questions, it would be helpful for a proxy  designated to answer some of the questions.  

It seems in some of the videos that there are gaps in the information presented that I would not expect in a course like this. 

While this course covers a LOT of JS and is quite comprehensive, it seems to be at the expense of other pertinent information.  

Brad usually puts together some excellent high quality courses, but I'm feeling a bit disappointed with this one.  I would recommend it to someone else but with the caveats I stated above.

results.content:
The course is great however the description is misleading:
"We start with the basic fundamentals and work our way to advanced programming WITHOUT relying on frameworks or libraries at all" -- He uses Bootstrap for many projects and then advertises his Bootstrap course in lieu of explaining the shorthand in depth. 
If you are completely new and don't know what Bootstrap is, it can be extremely confusing. Considering that there are many people out there who are learning HTML/CSS/JS all at the same time, it makes it hard to get a top-down understanding when there is a library being used that has it's own shorthand. It took me a while to realize where exactly the bootstrap was being used.
results.content_html:

results.content: Its a very good course, with example lectures for each section covering all the code you will then use to put together apps in later sections.  It does go along very fast for someone who is new to Javascript and I think experienced users would keep up better than us newbies who are constantly stopping the videos and scribbling down notes or looking over the code to wrap their head around it properly.  However, there is a lot of material covered here and Brad does a good job of making the course pretty thorough.

results.content:
I learn a lot from this course, but I gave only three stars for some reasons. First Brad is speaking and typing way too fast. If you want to follow on your own and not only download the files, you have no chance. So most of the videos took me twice the time, with pausing, stopping and going back. Second issue I have that sometimes I had the impresison that Brad is just saying what he is typing, without deeper explanation on what is this technology for. I am new to programming but few times I had this question in my had "why like this". On top of that we did the last project, which I don't really know what should it teach me, besides, that we have been typing "pure" js all the time, only to threw it all at the end end install bunch of extra tools and compilers.

To summarize, Brad has excelent knowledge. I liked the projects a lot. I liked that he used few different css frameworks. I will probably be going back to other Brad's courses

results.content: I've completed the course! This is a very good course.  I like that everything worked as Brad taught it.  This is a big deal for me.  I ran into issues along the way and inevitably it was my fault as I typed in something wrong.  But that was good because it helped me to learn more deeply and debug the application which is a very important skill to figure out how to solve the issues that cause you to stumble.  I've tried doing tutorials on the web(or using books) with different technologies and always run into roadblocks with the code not working as described and give up.  There is one caveat though, unfortunately, the Weather Underground API is no longer giving public keys.  But, this allowed me to go find another weather api and do some coding of my own to make the weather app work.

This course gave me many useful insights into how to structure my own projects. It really stressed to me the importance of knowing precisely what your code means and why to use a particular coding practice over others. Most importantly,  it really improved my confidence in using JS.

I would have liked to have seen more about how to correctly ensure you have proper and comprehensive live project validation. But, that's all. The rest of the course was perfectly explained, the projects were fun and applicable to the real world and there was a good amount of tips and tricks as well as extra tools to help improve my work flow. Thanks!

Brad is an incredible instructor, I've seen so many of his videos on youtube and decided to buy this course to start my path on Javascript.

Recommended for beginners and newcomers to JS.

Excellent, I'm posting this review after completing the whole course and I'm very pleased, the content is very comprehensive and teach a wide array of techniques and concepts in a very direct way, no more no less.

I know it's impossible to include absolutely everything about the language, but maybe a video or short section explaining the technical side of JS like the stack, the heap, event bubbling, etc. may help to understand more certain concepts.

Great for all levels of experience I recommend it 100% 

Great job!

results.content:
I can perhaps write a very very long review regarding how good this course is but in all honesty it's something you just have to experience for yourself! 

A little background on myself: I Started 'programming' back in college by taking a few classes here and there, learning basics of MatLab, Python, Java and to be quite honest I didn't like it much... 

Though recently (4 months as of this writing) I decided to pick up programming and begin applying it to my Startup. 

This course, along with all the other amazing content Brad provides has truly helped me out, and in turn helped my startup (close to getting a prototype up and running now)

Hope this review helps others :)

I very much enjoyed the course.  The objectives were well laid out from the start and the pace went as fast as I was willing and able to go.  I will definitely use this as reference material in the future when I need to apply this to real world applications.  The only constructive criticism around the course is that I would have liked to dive a little deeper into some of the later topics.  Those may be great candidates for separate courses.  

Thank you for a great learning experience.

This is the perfect bridge for any knowledge gap...and being self taught makes this course even more valuable.  If you feel like you are a beginner, stuck in between beginner and mid level or even advanced you will get something out of this course.

results.content: All I can say is WOW, Thank You Brad! My journey to this point has been long and arduous to say the least, but man was it worth it. Thanks to Brads extremely beginner friendly style yet thorough explanations, I have reached a point where landing a job(starting my career) seems like an inevitability. Both the Modern HTML & CSS and now Javascript courses have exceeded my expectations tenfold. The world needs more teachers like Brad and not just in TECH. His passion and expertise of the subject matter really shows through the very well structured lectures and projects. At this moment I am inspired to continue on my journey to delve deeper into Web Dev and work harder than ever before. All I can really say is THANK YOU so much my man. Best wishes to Brad and his family, and everyone who is on their journey, remember YOU ARE NOT ALONE, AND YOU CAN DO THIS...

results.content:
Today is March 29, 2019. 

Brad knows Javascript really, really well. If you're very beginner, his quick paste might be a little overwhelming to you at first. 

This doesn't cover from the very, very beginning. It doesn't cover the basic terminology or syntax kind of stuff. For those, I'd recommend learning from codecademy or youtube. Then once you believe you got the very basics down, take this course. 

At first, you might think he's going way too fast. I'd recommend watching the whole video first, then replay back and follow what he's doing. 

Overall, Brad is a master in this stuff. Good luck and have fun!

results.content: I am a software engineer by trade. The language hasn't been new to me. This said, it served as a good refresher on concepts and ideas behind the quirky JavaScript. Coming from languages like Assembly, C/C++, Java etc., this course serves as a good introduction to JavaScript language. Furthermore, it provides a good foundation which can be used to learn other libraries and frameworks. I would highly recommend.

results.content:
Brad does a fantastic job of explaining how, and more importantly, why things work the way they do.  He definitely knows his subject matter and presents it in well developed steps aimed at teaching one element of complex subject matter at a time.  

My only complaint was that he does not seem to be involved in the series afterwards.  I absolutely don't blame him for not responding to every little "this isn't working" request because that could be a full time job troubleshooting errors on an unknown system.  Other users have done a pretty good job of helping out there, and really, troubleshooting stupid little errors is part of being a developer. He should however have by now seen the many comments noting that he failed to upload the 'delete' video for the microposts project, and at least addressed it.  

Still highly recommend!

Thanks Brad!

results.content: Like the HTML&CSS course which I took before, this is a solid course as well. The pace is adequate, the repetitiveness allows me to remember stuff. Brad is very patient, empathetic, focuses on the important and can explain it clearly. For the first time in my life I am convinced I am really learning web development. I wanted to give 5 start, however, I have changed it to 4.5 because the section 11 was confusing and the section 12 was overwhelming. Still, this is a great course. I would recommend it to a friend and I would use the same course again if I wanted to get into JS. Brad helped me to really get going with JS and I have already built a few projects on my own. Thank you a lot, Brad. You are an incredibly great teacher.

results.content:
The tempo is somewhat overwhelming for a beginner seeing as there are no real clarifications or how to think or exercises in the beginning. You mainly get bombarded with descriptive information. It seems more like the beginner part was an afterthought to make sure to broaden who would enter.

If you are not a very quick learner this course will be highly challenging.
